editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).

1. RIGHT Honorable, right wor≈øhipfull, and dearelie beloued Countrymen giue me leaue to ioyne you all in one Epi≈øtle, whom I contayne in one bre≈øt of loue, and include in one lincke of entire affection. Wherin to helpe you the better to di≈øcerne true gold from ≈øhyninge bra≈ø≈øe, true religion from fal≈øe and counterfeit. I haue framed for you a Prudentiall Balance of Religion. by which euery one of you, may by the weightes and rules of right rea≈øon,

VVhy this cour≈øe of comparinge religions is taken.2. And this cour≈øe of comparinge the≈øe two religions together I haue taken before any other, becau≈øe as the Philo≈øopher teacheth and experience confirmeth. Contraria iuxta ≈øe po≈øita magis eluce≈øcunt: Contraries put together do more apppeare. As beautie in pre≈øence of deformitie ≈øeemeth more gratious and deformitie more vglie; Truth before lies appeareth more loue lye, and lies more odious; vertue before vice more amiable, and vice more dete≈øtable. Euery thinge as it were ≈øtriuinge to ≈øhew it ≈øelfe more when it is ≈øet as it were to wra≈øtle with the contrarie. And I haue made choy≈øe of comparinge the≈øe religions accordinge to the rules of ttue prudence and right rea≈øon,VVhy the comparinge of religions accordinge to rules of vvi≈ødome is cho≈øen before others. rather then otherwi≈øe, as the mo≈øt generall, mo≈øt ea≈øie, mo≈øt euident, and mo≈øt effectuall for all ≈øortes of people. for albeit Catholiques & Prote≈øtants agree that to be the true religion of God which is mo≈øt agreable to his word, yet ≈øith they neyther agree which is his word, (Prote≈øtants reiectinge much of that which Catholiques reuerence for Gods heauenly word)
nor which is they ≈øen≈øe therof,Thus Tertullian lib. de prae≈øcript. proued by‚ñ™ rea≈øon the Cath. religion to be preferred befor anie here≈øie. they can not be brought to agree about one balance of Gods word wherby they may weigh their religions together. Be≈øides that not onely Catholicks teach but al≈øo Prote≈øtants confe≈ø≈øe, that the weaker ≈øorte of Chri≈øtians can not iudge which is the true expo≈øition of Scriptures. And therfor to weighe religions to them by the balance of Scripture,D. Reinolds Confer. pag. 149. were to weigh one vnknowne thing by an other. But the weights of Prudence and right rea≈øon are both commun and euident to all, & therfor the weighinge of religions by them mu≈øt needs be mo≈øt generall, mo≈øt ea≈øie, and mo≈øt effectual with all ≈øortes of people. And if anie refu≈øe to haue their religion tried by the≈øe kinds of weights,VVhat religion is again≈øt vvi≈ødom and rea≈øon is follie. they confe≈ø≈øe therby that they fear their religion to be contrarie to wi≈ødome and rea≈øon, which is as much as to be fabulous and fooli≈øh. 3. Nether let anie think that that religion which is mo≈øt agreable to Prudence and the light of rea≈øon, is not al≈øo mo≈øt agreable to Scripture. Becau≈øe rea≈øon and Scripture are both God his word and Gods truth, the one naturall, written by his owne hand in our ≈øoules by creation; the other ≈øupernatural, written in paper
with the hands of his holie Scribes by reuelation.The agreablenes of Religion and rea≈øon. And therfor though the≈øe two words be of different degree they can not be contrarie, but rather as twinnes of one and the ≈øelf ≈øame parent haue great ≈øympathie and connexion together. For as God doth not by his grace de≈øtroie the naturall inclination of our will to good but perfecteth it: So by his word and faith he extingui≈øheth not but increa≈øeth the naturall in≈øight which our vnder≈øtanding hath of truthe. yea ≈øuch is the force of our vnder≈øtanding to pearce into Gods truth as that by it the Philo≈øophers (as the Apo≈øtle witne≈ø≈øeth Rom. 1.) came to know the inui≈øible proprieties of God and his euerla≈øting power & diuinitie. S. Paul. And ≈øith we ≈øee that men by the light of rea≈øon know ≈øo much of other moral vertues as without all other teaching they perceaue in manie things what is hone≈øt, what di≈øhone≈øt, what iu≈øt, what vniu≈øt, what is vertue, what vice, why ≈øhould we doubt that God hath giuen to vs equal knowledge of matters of religion and wor≈øhip of him ≈øelf. Which vertue as it is the cheefe≈øt of all morall vertues, ≈øo the knowledge therof is mo≈øt nece≈ø≈øaire of them all vnto vs. Yea S. Au≈øtin accounted ≈øo much of Rea≈øon as lib. de vtil. credendi cap. 12. he ≈øaid that Recta ratio e≈øt ip≈øa virtus. S. Au≈øtin. becau≈øe it
is the naturall ≈øquare and rule which God euen in creation giueth to euery one to know what he ought to do.Calvvin. And Caluin ≈øaith that Semen religionis e≈øt in mente humana. And Doctor Reinolds in his conference pag. 207. ≈øaith, Rea≈øon is a notable helpe of mans weaknes. This rule therfor of naturall rea≈øon and prudence giuen vnto vs by God, common and euident to all authorized by verdit of the Apo≈øtle, confirmed by rea≈øon and approued by con≈øent both of Catholiques and Prote≈øtantes is that wherwith I intend to direct you in the choyce of Religion, and the Balance wherwith I purpo≈øe to to weigh before your eyes the two more famous religions which are in our Lande.

of Gods word wronglie vnder≈øtoode, which euery Hereticke can and doth giue, and which when it is oppo≈øite (as it is heere) to true vertue, lawfull mi≈øsion, right orders and vndoubted miracles, is (as is ≈øhewed before and ≈øhall more heerafter) but a vayne colour ≈øhew and ≈øhadowe of rea≈øon, much le≈ø≈øe able to defend your doinges either before men now or God at the latter day. div.head: TO THE READER.
div.p:
TVVo onelie meanes (Gentle Reader) hath allmightie God giuen vs to be a≈ø≈øured of truth.Tvvo onely vvaies to be certaine. Science. Beleef. The one by Science of euident truth which we our ≈øelues do know. The other by Beleefe of euident authoritie of others, who in like manner do know, and who≈øe te≈øtimonie we haue no iu≈øt cau≈øe to mi≈øtru≈øt. And therfor as he who should reiect euident rea≈øon, should both be vnrea≈øonable in fightinge again≈øt rea≈øon and iniurious both to God and him≈øelfe by refu≈øinge a meane which God hath giuen him to atttayne to truth.VVhy good authoritye aught to be beleued. So likewi≈øe he who should reiect euident Authoritie should both do again≈øt rea≈øon which biddeth him giue creditt to ≈øuch authoritie, and be iniurious to God and him ≈øelfe by ca≈øtinge away ≈øuch a meane as God gaue him to a≈ø≈øure him ≈øelfe of ≈øuch truth as by him≈øelfe he could not know, and finallie should be an enemie to humaine ≈øocietie which cannot ≈øtand vnles men do creditt one an other in thinges wherin they haue no cau≈øe to di≈øtru≈øt them for what should we know of things pa≈øt before our time, or of thinges done out of our ≈øight, if we would not beleeue ≈øuch as were pre≈øent and knew them, and ether by word or writing haue reported them to vs. How should we know ≈øuch to be our parents but by beleefe? How should any matter be tryed in Law but by beleefe of mens wordes or writinges, what familiaritie, humayne ≈øocietie or frendship could ≈øtand if we admitt not beleefe?
VVherfor abbeit it be a fault to beleeue vpon light or ≈ømall te≈øtimonie (which kind of beleeuers the ≈øcripture tearmeth light of hart) as it is a fault to a≈ø≈øent to any friuolous rea≈øon: yet contrariwi≈øe it is a greater fault not to giue credit to euident ≈øufficient authoritie, as it is not to yeild to euident rea≈øon. For in beleuinge vpon weake authoritie we do but preiudice our ≈øelues, but in not beleeuinge ≈øufficient authoritie we hinder our ≈øelues from knowledge of truth, di≈øcredit our owne reportes to others, do again≈øt rea≈øon which as well bindeth vs to yeild to euident authoritie, as to euident rea≈øon, di≈øcredit our neighbors and cut in ≈øunder the very ≈øinowes of humane frendship and ≈øocietie.lib. de vtil. Cred. cap. 16.

VVherfor wel ≈øaid S. Au≈øtin that though it be mi≈øerable to be deceaued by authority, yet mo≈øt mi≈øerable it is not to be moued with authoritie. And mo≈øt vnrea≈øonably do ≈øome Mini≈øters,Hovv manie things vvhich are not in ≈øcripture are yet to be beleued. ≈øay that they are not bound to beleeue the great vertues or miracles of Saints in times pa≈øt, though neuer ≈øo authentically recorded, becau≈øe they be not in ≈øcripture. Indeed if we vrged them to beleue the≈øe thinges with diuine and chri≈øtian faith they might haue ≈øome colourable excu≈øe of ≈øuch ≈øpeech, becau≈øe (as they ≈øay) all poyntes of chri≈øtian faitb are in ≈øcripture. But ≈øith we vrge them onelie to giue humane beleefe to ≈øuch matters, either they mu≈øt shew ≈øome cau≈øe why the authority of ≈øuch writers is not ≈øufficient to giue humane credite vnto the thinges by them recorded, or they mu≈øt reiect all humane authoritie,
all mens wordes or writinges, and beleeue nothinge but what either God hath written, or them ≈øelues haue ≈øeene. for if Scripture mu≈øt be the onelie ≈øquare of all our beleife both humane and Dyuine, we mu≈øt beleue nothing but what God haeh written, no not that ≈øuch were our parentes, that ther are Turkes Moores ar any ≈øuch thinge as the Scripture mentioneth not. Or if we admitt (as we mu≈øt needes) that humane authority by either word or writinge may be ≈øufficient for vs to beleue thinges with humayne faith, as vve beleue ≈øuch to be our parentes, and the like, vve mu≈øt not thinke it rea≈øon to reiect a thinge, becau≈øe it is not in Scripture,Inconueniences of not beleuing mens authoritie but vve mu≈øt all≈øo shevv ≈øome rea≈øon, vvhy ≈øuch authoritie as te≈øtifieth it, is not ≈øufficient for a vvi≈øe man to giue credit vnto: or els we mu≈øt confe≈ø≈øe our ≈øelues to be vvilfull, to reiect ≈øufficient authoritie vvithout, yea again≈øt rea≈øon; to be in iurious to God and our ≈øelues in reiecting a meane vvhich he hath be≈øtovved vpon vs, for to knovv truth; Iniurious to our neighbours in di≈øcreditinge them vvithout cau≈øe; and finallie pernicious to all good frendshipp and ≈øocietie vvhich vvithout beleefe of humane authoritie cannot ≈øtand. And to preuent Mini≈øters that they shall not delude the Reader by ≈øayinge that the authoritie vvhich I alleadge for vvhat I ≈øay of Saint Au≈øtin and Luther is not ≈øufficient.Onely Prote≈øtaÃÑts alledged for vvhat is ≈øaid of Luther. commended. for albeit I might iu≈øtlie alleadge the te≈øtimonies of Catholiques again≈øt Luther as I shew heerafter lib. 2. cap. 1. yet partelie to avoyd all cauills, but principallie becau≈øe Prote≈øtantes te≈øtifie ynough again≈øt him, I omitt this aduantage. And the vvitne≈ø≈øes vvhich I produce for vvhat I vvrite of S. Au≈øtin, are partelie the ≈øaid Prote≈øtants, partely Catholikes, but ≈øuch Catholiques as ≈øome of them are great Saintes, ≈øome great Clarkes, ≈øome lyued vvhen the thinges vvere done vvhich they vvritt, ≈øome vvere dome≈øticall, ≈øome forrayne, and all vvere before this controuer≈øie betvvene Prote≈øtants and Catholikes aro≈øe, and all are greatlie e≈øteemed of Prote≈øtants as shall appeare in the Catalogue en≈øuinge, and finallie all are conte≈øted and approued in their te≈øtimonies of diuers Prote≈øtants as shall appeare heerafter. VVhich kind of te≈øtimonie I hope no indifferent man guided vvith rea≈øon vvill account vn≈øufficient. And for other ob≈øtinat per≈øons who (as S. Hierome ≈øaith) are wount ≈øhutting their eyes to denie what they will not beleue, I wrot not this vvorke for as S. Au≈øtin adui≈øeth vs vve should rather pray for the≈øe kind of men than rea≈øon vvhith them.For vvhat Readers this booke is vvritten. But novv let vs come to the Catalogue of the Catholike vvriters, and after of the Prote≈øtantes.

div.head: A CATALOGVE Of the cheife Catholike vvriters Vpon who≈øe te≈øtimonies the Authour relieth for what he writeth of Saint Au≈øtin.
div.p: A ALCVIN, liued in the eight age after Chri≈øt which was the ≈øecond of the conuer≈øion of our Nation to the Chri≈øtian faith. He was ≈øcholler to S. Bede and Mai≈øter to the famous Emperor Charles the great of whom what high e≈øteeme Prote≈øtants make, you may ≈øee. Infra. lib. 1. cap. 12.

B BEDA, liued with in the fir≈øt hundred yeares after the conuer≈øion of our Nation and therfore might well learne the truth therof. How greatlie he is accounted of by Prote≈øtantes both for vertue and learninge, you may read. lib. 1. cap. 12. cit. onelie becau≈øe his te≈øtimonie is that, vpon which I principallie relie in what I ≈øay of S. Au≈øtin. I would heere add what Godwin in the life of Tatwin Archbishop of Canterburie ≈øaith, that His hi≈øtorie is the mo≈øt auncient that England hath worthie of credit, And that Cambden in Britan. pag. 12. giueth him this te≈øtimonie that he is. Inter omnes no≈øtros ≈øcriptores veritatis amicus among≈øt all our writers a frend of truth. And what him≈øelfe hath in his Epi≈øtle to King Cealwulph to put (as he ≈øaith) all that heare or read it out of doubt of the veritie therof, that vvhat he writeth of S. Au≈øtin and his fellowes he learned of Albinus a man (≈øaith he) of great learninge, brought vp vnder S. Theodor Archbi≈øhop, and Adrian both men of great wor≈øhip and learning, which thinges (≈øaith he) the ≈øaid Albinus knew partely by writinge, partlye by tradition of Elders, and ≈øent to me by
Nothelmus, Bale. Cent. 2. cap. 8. calleth this Nothelmus a learned and graue man who after was Archbishop of Canterburie. Be≈øides this the ≈øaid Hi≈øtorie vvas approued by the ≈øaid King Cealwulph, and by all writers ≈øince, and is the verie fountayne of all our English Chronicles, who≈øe credit depend vpon it. And therfor if it be reiected, all our auncient Chronicles may be contemned as fables, or vncertayne tales.

C
CAPGRAVI, lyued vnder King Henry the fixt. He was (≈øaith Bale Centuria. 8. cap. 1.) Doctor of Diuinitie of Oxford, and Prouinciall of the Au≈øtin fryers, the cheife diuine and Phili≈øopher of his tyme, of a cleare witt and vtterance, he loued the Scriptures ≈øingularly, and commented the greate≈øt part of the Bible, and was Confe≈ø≈øour to Humfrey Duke of Gloce≈øter.

E EALRID liued vnder King Henry the ≈øecond. He was (≈øaith Bale Cent. 2. cap. 99. famous for birth, for learning, and for innocent life. He in ≈øhort time excelled all his fellowes in all ornaments of life, left no kind of learning vntouched, refu≈øed a Bi≈øpoprike the better to excerci≈øe vertue, and to preach the Gospell. He was an other Bernard, mild in di≈øpo≈øition, pious in action, and mo≈øt mode≈øt in Coun≈øell, and was a godlie man. And in all kind of vvriting mo≈øt like to Bernard. Thus Bale.

ETHELWERDVS, ≈øeemeth (≈øaith Cambden in de≈øcrip Brit. 100.) to haue bene great grand child to King Adulph, and liued about the yeare. 950. His booke was publi≈øhed by Prote≈øtants with Malmes burien≈øis and others. Sauill who publi≈øhed him, ≈øaith, he is to be commended for his nobilitie and antiquitie.

F.
FLORENTIVS, liued vnder King Henry the fir≈øt. He vvas (≈øaith Bale. Cent. 2. c. 66.) very learned
both in diuine and humane literature, and gott great fame by his vvriting. He had (≈øaith Bale) a vvit apt for any thinge, and an excellent memorie, let no day pa≈ø≈øe vvherin he did not ≈øome vvhat for the honour of his Countrie, and calleth his Chronicle an excellent comment, which al≈øo is printed by Prote≈øtantes.

G S. GREGORY, the great was the cheefe Author next after God of the conuer≈øion of our Engli≈øh Nation vnto Chri≈øtianitie, and lyued eight yeares after he had ≈øent S. Au≈øtin hither, and had heard of great fruit of his labours. He is one of the famous Doctors of the Church, and greatlie reuerenced of Prote≈øtantes as you may ≈øee infra. lib. 1. cap. 5.

GILDAS, ≈øyrnamed the vvi≈øe, a Britan, florished about the yeare. 580. which was eighteen yeares before S. Au≈øtins comming hither. He vvas (≈øaith Bale Cent. 1. cap. 66. out of Polidor) a mo≈øt graue Author, hauinge vvell learnt liberall ≈øciences, gaue him≈øelfe vvholie to ≈øtudie the Scriptures and ledd a mo≈øt innocent life. This mans writinges al≈øo haue bene publi≈øhed by Prote≈øtantes, and I produce his te≈øtimonie cheiflie to ≈øhew what was the Religion of the auncient Britons.

GEFFOREY of Monmonth lyued vnder King Stephen. He vvas (≈øaith Bale Cent. 2. cap. 86,) a Briton and learned both in ver≈øe and proofe, and he highlie commendeth his diligence, and ≈øaith he excellentlie de≈øerueth of his Countrie. Thus he and other Prote≈øtantes account of this Geffrey, which maketh me to alleadge his authoritie again≈øt them though Catholickes for the mo≈øt part account him but a fabulous Authour, and his bookes be forbidden by the Councell of Trent, and Cambden Britan. pag. 8. calleth his hi≈øtorie, Ineptias, fooleries.

H HOVEDEN lyued vnder kinge Iohn, He vvas (≈øaith Bale Cent. 3. cap. 55) of a noble race, and a famous Chronographer. His hi≈øtorie was publi≈øhed by Savill, and dedicated to Queene Elizabeth, wher togither with Huntington he is called a very good and diligent Authour, and mo≈øt true guide of the times pa≈øt.

HVNTINGTON, liued vnder King Stephen. He vvas (≈øaith Bale cent. 2. cap. 82. out of Polidor and Leland) an excellent Hi≈øtoriographer, and approued Authour, and vvrit (≈øaith he) finely and learnedly. He is acounted of Cambden in Britan. pag. 306. an Authour pri≈øcae fidei. Of Doctor Caius lib. de antiquit. Cantabr. pag. 64. Summus Hi≈øtoricus. And his hi≈øtory was publ ‚Ä¢ ≈øhed by Savill with the fore≈øaid commendations. Fluyd in de≈øcript. Monae calleth him eg ‚Ä¢ egium Hi≈øtoricum.
I. INGVLPHVS, lyued in the time of the Conque≈øt, & is much de≈øired (≈øaith Sauil who publi≈øhed him) of very many, vvho de≈øire to knovv our Antiquities.

M MALMESBVRIENSIS, lyued vnder Kinge Stephen, He vvas (≈øaith Sauil who publi≈øhed him, in his epi≈øtle to Queene Elizabeth) among≈øt the faithfull recorders of thinges done the cheefe, both for truth of Hi≈øtorie, and for Maturitie of iudgment, very learned, and hath compri≈øed the hi≈øtorie of Seauen hundred yeares vvith ≈øuch fidelitie and diligence, that he may ≈øeeme of all ours to haue bene the onelie Hi≈øtoriographer. Camb. in Brit pag. 514. calleth him. Optimum Hi≈øtoricum. an excellent Hi≈øtoriographer. Bale Cent. 2. cap. 73. ≈øaith playnelie he was the mo≈øt learned of his age in all kinde of good learning, and of ≈øingular vvitt, diligence and indu≈øtrie in ≈øearchinge all Antiquites, and
compiled a fine and mo≈øt excellent Hi≈øtorie. And this man ≈øo highlie commended by Prote≈øtants is the Authour vpon whom next after S. Bede I relie, and the edition which I cite of his hi≈øtorie and of Huntington, Houeden, and Ingulph, is of Franckford Anno. 1601. infol.

MARIANVS, liued at the time of the Conque≈øt, He vvas (≈øaith Bale Cent. 14. cap. 45.) learned both in diuinitie and Humanitie, and lyued all mo≈øt thirtie yeares ≈øolitarie vvith admiration of all men and continuallie ≈øtudied He is accounted an excellent Hi≈øtoriographer a ≈øingular Calculator, and a graue diuine, vvhich titles ≈øaith he to this d ‚Ä¢ y all vvriters de giue him. Thus Bale. Cambd. in Brit. pag. 321. calleth him an Hi≈øtoriographer. Antiquae fidei.

N. NEVBRIGENSIS, lyued vnder Kinge Iohn. He vvas (≈øaith Bale Cent. 3. cap. 53.) Doctor of diuinity ≈øcarce let any hovver p ‚Ä¢ ≈ø≈øe vvithout reading of learned bookes, and vvrote a Hi≈øtorie vvith a cleare ≈øtile.

O. OSBERNE, liued vnder Kinge William Conqueror. He vvas (≈øaith Bale Cent. 2. cap. 54) mo≈øt familiar and invvard vvith Archbi≈øhop Lanfrancke, vvas the excellente≈øt Mu≈øycion of his time, and had a flori≈øhing and eloquent ≈øtile.
OTTERBVRNE, He vvrote (≈øaith Bale Cent. 7. cap. 75. out of Leland) a hi≈øtorie ≈øincerely, though his cheefe ≈øtudies vvere in Phi ‚Ä¢ o≈øophy and Diuinitie.

P. PARIS, lyued vnder King Henry the third. He vvas (≈øaith Bale Cent. 4. cap. 26.) from his infancie brought vp in learning, and continuallie at ≈øtudie. And vvrote a Hi≈øtorie
from the conque≈øt vnto the thirtie fift yeare of the ≈øaid King Henrie vvith mo≈øt great diligence and fidelitie. And for his ≈øingular giftes both of bodie and minde vvas deere to that King, at vvho≈øe commande he vvrot his Actes. This authour is much e≈øteemed by Prote≈øtants, becau≈øe ≈øome times he inueigheth bitterly again≈øt ≈øome acts of the Pope of his time, and therfor was publi≈øhed by them, and greatly commended in the preface by the pretended Archbi≈øhop Parker, as it is thought.

W. VVALSINGHAM, lyued vnder King Henry the Sixt. He vvas (≈øaith Bale Cent. 7. cap. 88. out of Leland) ≈øtudious & diligent in Hi≈øtories. He is much commended by the Prote≈øtantes, who publi≈øhed him, in a Preface before his hi≈øtorie, who is thought to haue bene pret. Archbi≈øhop Parker. VVESTMONASTERIENSIS, lyued vnder King Edward the fir≈øt. He did (≈øaith Bale Cent. 6. cap. 31.) labour ≈øingularlie in vvriting, and vvas in all kind of learninge of his time very learned, and compo≈øed a Chronicle vvith notable paynes, which Bale tearmed an excellent and fruitfull vvorke, and it hath bene printed by Prote≈øtants with great commendations. And in the arraignment of F. Garnet, he is called by a Prote≈øtant noble man a vvitnes of be≈øt regard accordinge to the ≈øtate of tho≈øe times. Thus many, thus auncient (to omitt the famous Baronius and other later writers al≈øo alleadged) & thus e≈øteemed of Prote≈øtants the ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ≈øelues are the Authors who≈øe te≈øtimonies I produce for what I ≈øay of S. Au≈øtin and his ≈øucce≈ø≈øors, and of our Kings, and our forefathers religion. VVho≈øe te≈øtimonie whether Mini≈øters admitt or refu≈øe they are ouerthrowne. For if they admitt them they are clearlie condemned, and if they refu≈øe them, they are contemned. For in matters
of Antiquitie to refu≈øe to be tryed by ≈øo many, ≈øo auncient, ≈øo indifferent writers, and ≈øo much commended by them ≈øelues, and to ≈øay, and that without te≈øtimonie of one equall writer to the contrarie, that they were all either deceaued or lyed, what other is it, than vtterlie to condemne them ≈øelues and their cau≈øe, as not able to abide the onelie triall, which can be made of auncient matters, that is by hi≈øtories and auncient recordes? will they not credit ≈øuch hi≈øtories as them ≈øelues iudge worthie of credit? will they not beleeue ≈øuch writers as them ≈øelues account e≈øpeciall freinds of truth, of ≈øingular fidelitie, diligence, and indifferent and mo≈øt excellent Hi≈øtoriographers? will they not follow them in matters of Antiquitie, whom them ≈øelues tearme the mo≈øt true guides of the times pa≈øt? What other thinge were this than ob≈øtinatelie to refu≈øe truth it ≈øelfe. But much more will this appeare when they ≈øhall be found not onelie to refu≈øe our writers, though neuer ≈øo auncient and indifferent and e≈øteemed of them ≈øelues, but euen their owne be≈øt writers or els be condemned. Let vs ≈øee therfor the Prote≈øtant writers whom we produce as witne≈ø≈øes in this triall of Religions.

div.head: A CATHALOGVE Of the cheefe Prote≈øtaÃÑt vvriters On who≈øe te≈øtimonies the Authour relieth for what he writeth of S. Au≈øtin and Luther.
div.p: A. ABBOTS, Doctor and Profe≈ø≈øour of Diuinitie, & now an earne≈øt writer both again≈øt Cardinall Bellarmin, and Doctor Bi≈øhop.

B. BALE, Bi≈øhop of O≈ø≈øorie in Ireland in King Edward the Sixt time, as him ≈øelfe writeth Cent. 8. cap. 100. and one of the fir≈øt Engli≈øh Preachers of Prote≈øtanti≈øme in time of King Henrie, for which both vnder him and after vnder Queene Marie he ≈øuffered as he ≈øaith much. As for his skill in Antiquities, he writeth of him≈øelfe in his Epi≈øtle before his foureteeneth Centurie that he had Antiquitatum penetralia, & incognitas orbi Hi≈øtorias, and in the Epi≈øtle before the thirteenth Centurie that he had read the hi≈øtories and Chronicles allmo≈øt of all Antiquities. And how earne≈øt a Prote≈øtant he was, appeareth both by his ≈øaid ≈øufferinges, and all≈øo by his mo≈øt ≈øpitefull kind of writinge again≈øt Catholiques, which is ≈øo great, as it ≈øeemeth malice did po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øe the hart, tongue, and penn of that man, and him≈øelfe is fayne to excu≈øe it in his epi≈øtle to the Counte Palatin. Of the Authour of the daungerous po≈øitions he is reckoned among≈øt their learned men who in the beginning of Queene Elizabeths raygne Came out of Germanie and of other Prote≈øtants often times cited.Reinoldes in his Confer. Abbots de Antichri≈øo The booke which I alledge of this man is his Centuries of the writeers of Britanie, edit. Ba≈øileae. 1559. in fol. BILSON, at this pre≈øent the pretended Bi≈øhop of winche≈øter, and well knowne for his writinges both again≈øt Catholiques and Puritanes.
C. CAIVS, Doctor of Phi≈øicke and halfe founder of Gonell and Caius Colledge in Cambridge. So well ≈øeene in Engli≈øhe Antiquities, as by an Oxonian Orator, he is tearmed the Antiquarie.
CALVIN, is more famous among Prote≈øtants than I need note him, and of ≈øuch account among≈øt many as Doctor Couel ≈øaith his writinges were made allmo≈øt the rule of Controuer≈øies.

CAMBDEN, well knowne for his di≈øcription of Britanye, and tearmed of Prote≈øtants an excellent Antiquarie and greatlie commended of diuers in ver≈øes before his booke. The edition of his booke cited by me is Londini Anno. 1600. in quarto.
COWPER, pretended Bi≈øhop fir≈øt of Lyncolne and after of Winche≈øter, well knowne for his Dictionarie and his Chronicle.

D DAVNGEROVS Po≈øitioner, So I tearme the vnnamed Authour of a booke called Daungerous Po≈øitions, by ≈øome thought to be the worke of Doctor Bancrofte now pretended Bi≈øhop of Canterburie, by others of Doctor Sutclife.

F. FOX, mo≈øt famous among≈øt Prote≈øtants for his Acts & monuments of their Martyrs, which they haue ≈øo credited, as they haue ≈øet it in diuers of their Churches to be read of all. To omitt diuers high prai≈øes giuen to him, as you may ≈øee in the beginning of his booke. Ford vpon the Apocalips calleth him mo≈øt holie father. Doctor Abbots in his booke of Antichri≈øt cap. 8. tearmeth him a man of mo≈øt famous memorie; a mo≈øt graue, and mo≈øt pious man, and plainlie a diuine man. Bale Cent. 9. cap. 92. ≈øaith he was his Achates.

FVLKE, Doctor of diuinitie and a great writer again≈øt Catholiques: whom I. B. alias Bac≈øter in tayle of two legged foxes. cap. 13. thus pray≈øeth profound fulke, vvho≈øe truth and great trauell the Church of God hath tryed, many a fox ha≈øt thou had in cha≈øe not able to abide thy hote pur≈øuite. Doctor Reynolds in his
preface before his Six Conclu≈øions calleth him a ≈øtout and faithfull ≈øouldier of Chri≈øt.
G GODWIN, now Subdeane of Exce≈øter, & ≈øonne to Godwin pret. Bi≈øhope of Bathe, as him≈øelfe ≈øaith in his Cathalogue of Bi≈øhopes.
H HOLINSHED, notorious for his great Chronicle, and mo≈øt earne≈øt again≈øt Catholikes as you may ≈øee by what he writeth of S. Au≈øtin.

HVMPHREY, Doctor of Deuinitie and the Queenes Reader therof in Oxford, whom I. B. loc. cit. thus comendeth Humphrey of much reading in thy time pa≈øt, vvas then a cheefe hunter of the Romish fox. And Bale Cent. 9. cap. 93. highly commendeth him.
I IEWELL, ≈øo famous and knowne to Prote≈øtantes as I need ≈øay nothinge.
L LVTHER, the father of Prote≈øtancie, and of what high account he is among≈øt Prote≈øtants you may ≈øee infra lib. 3. cap. 1.
R. REYNOLDS, Doctor of Diuinitie who, ≈øaith I. B. loc. cit. hath the old fox and his cubbs in the cha≈øe.
S. STOW, well knowne for his Chronicle and others his writinges of Antiquitie.
SVTCLIFE, Doctor of Diuinitie and Deane of Exce≈øter, and a great writer again≈øt Catholikes.
SVRVEYER, ≈øo I call the vnnamed Authour of the Suruey of the pretended holie Di≈øcipline, by ≈øome taken to be the worke of the ≈øaid Doctor Sutclife, by others the worke of the Lord of Canterburie.

W. WHITAKER, Doctor and Profe≈ø≈øour of Diuinitie, and a great writer again≈øt Catholiques, whom I. B. loc. cit. calleth vvorthie VVhitaker of neuer dyinge fame. Doctor Willet in his Tetra≈øtylon pag. 9. tearmeth him a vvorthie and learned man. pag. 10. a godlie learned man. Doctor Bucley in his Apologie of religion pag. 84. An excellent man of ble≈ø≈øed memorie. The≈øe and thus e≈øteemed of Prote≈øtants are the Prote≈øtant writers, vpon who≈øe confe≈øsion or te≈øtimonie I cheefly relie in what I write of S. Au≈øtin and Luther. Again≈øt who≈øe verdict no Prote≈øtant can iu≈øtlie take exception either of ignorance, becau≈øe they are of the cheefe≈øt writers they haue, or for partialitie, for they were all mo≈øt earne≈øt Prote≈øtantes. And therfor no Prote≈øtant can iu≈øtlie reiect their te≈øtimonie as in≈øufficient.

3. The Chri≈øtian faith thus receaued, the Britons kept not onely ≈øound,Gildas de oxcid c. 7. div.head: CHAP. II. That S. Austin was the first Preacher of the Chri≈øtian Faith to our English Nation.
div.p:
THat our Engli≈øh Nation came hither out of Germanie, being ≈øent for of the Britons to ayde them again≈øt the Scotts, and Picts, all Hi≈øtoriographers agree, but they di≈øagree ≈øomwhat about the tyme. Au≈øtin was the fir≈øt preacher of Chri≈øtian faith vnto our Engli≈øh Nation here in England,S. And ≈øurely I here admire the goodnes of God towards our Nation, that he would Saint Au≈øtin ≈øhould enquire ≈øuch ≈ømall matters of S. Gregory, and that his que≈øtions ≈øhould remaine to our dayes. both to ≈øhew vs by our fir≈øt Apo≈øtle what account we ≈øhould make of the re≈øolution of the Sea Apo≈øtolick,VVhat account S. Au≈øtin made of the re≈øolutions of the See Apo≈øtol. and (as S. Irenaeus lib. 3. c. 3. wrote aboue 1400. yeares ago) in all difficulties recur to her, and al≈øo to a≈ø≈øure vs that S. Au≈øtin, who in ≈øo ≈ømall matters would do nothing of him≈øelfe, but by the direction of S. Gregory, would much le≈ø≈øe vary from him in matters of faith or religion; And con≈øequently, that the faith which he taught our Ance≈øtors, was the faith of the greate≈øt Doctor that euer ≈øince S. Peter ≈øate in the Church of Rome,Belt. VVoful cry p. 3. and by the confe≈øsion of Prote≈øtants was as famous and as learned a man as euer was Bishop of Rome, yea omnium Pontificum, Of all the Bishops
of Rome, the mo≈øt excellent for life and learning. Bale cent. 1. c. 68. Which thing wel coÃÑ ≈øidered, can not but breed great comfort in them, who had the faith of their Forfathers deliuered to them by S. Au≈øtin, and as great di≈øcomfort in them, who haue for≈øaken it. And thus much of S. Au≈øtins learning: now let vs ≈øee his vertue.

div.head: CHAP. V. That Saint Austin was a great Saint, and holy man.
div.p:
IF Mini≈øters were before vnwilling to grant that S. Au≈øtin was our fir≈øt Preacher or a learned man, much more loth they are to confe≈ø≈øe that he was a holy man. And not without cau≈øe, becau≈øe therby they perceaue it will follow, that his faith was the true faith of Chri≈øt. For as S. Paul ≈øaith Rom. 10. The iu≈øt man liueth by faith. & Heb. 11. without faith it is impo≈øsible to plea≈øe God. By hovv manie kinds of te≈øtimonies S. Au≈øtins great holines is proued. But I will prooue not onely by the te≈øtimonie of them that ≈øaw, and knew S. Au≈øtin, but al≈øo by the te≈øtimony of his Mai≈øter, his own life and death, by publick and priuat te≈øtimony of them that liued with him, by all kind
of writers following, by the vertuous life of the Church which he founded, and finally by the confe≈øsion of diuers Prote≈øtants that S. Au≈øtin was a ≈øaint and vertuous holy man.

2. As for S. Au≈øtins Mai≈øter, Ambro≈ø. lib. 2. de Virginibus. ≈øaith:Hovv vertuous S. Au≈øtins Mai≈øter vvas. The fir≈øt ≈øpur to learning is the excelleÃÑcy of the Mai≈øter. And no doubt but the example of an excellent Mai≈øter is a great ≈øpur to vertue. And what Mai≈øter ether in that age, or long before, or after could S. Au≈øtin haue had comparable to S. Gregory, who for his great vertue, and noble acts is ≈øurnamed the great: whome S. I≈øidor lib. de viris illu≈øtrib. c. 7. who knew him ≈øaith,S. I≈øidor. was by compunction ful of the feare of God, in humilitie cheefe≈øt, and endued with ≈øuch light of knowledg, as the like was not then, nor before. 8. Councel Tolet. And the 8. Councel of Toledo doubteth not to prefer him in morall doctrine before all other Doctors.S. Ildefon≈øus. S. Ildefon≈øus al≈øo lib. de vir. illu≈øtrib. c. 2. writeth that he excelled ≈øo high in perfection of all vertues, as ≈øetting a ≈øide all famous men, antiquitie could not shew the like. For in holines he ≈øurpa≈ø≈øed S. Antony, in eloquence S. Cyprian, in knowledg S. Au≈øtin. S. Gregor. Turon. S. Gregor. al≈øo of Tours, who knew him greatly coÃÑmendeth him lib. 10. de Ge≈øtis Francorum. c. 1. S. Beda lib. 1. c. 13. ≈øaith, S. Beda See S. Dama≈øen orat. 2. de defunctis. He was a man of the greate≈øt vertue & learning of his tyme. And who will ≈øee more of this vertuous
man may reade his life in Ioannes Diacon. in S. Beda lib. 2. c. 1. Here I will content my ≈øelf with the iudgment of our famous and ancient King Alfred:K. Alfred who thus commendeth him. The true ≈øeruant of God the Roman Pope Chri≈øts Vicar Gregory, a man of con≈øiderat fortitude, King Alfred Praefat. Pa≈øtoral. without rashnes, indued with cheefe wit, wi≈ødome and Coun≈øel, an infinit trea≈øor, becau≈øe he wonne the greate≈øt part of mankinde to heauen, the be≈øt man of the Romans, mo≈øt abounding in greatnes of courage, and mo≈øt free of Maie≈øtie. This was the iudgment of our great King touching S. Gregory, and of the ≈øame minde were all our Catholick writers, as yow may ≈øee in FloreÃÑt. an. 605. Malmesb. 1. Reg. c. 3. We≈øtmon. an. 605. and others. In ≈øo much as D. Reinolds in his Confer. p. 583.Ancient English men. writeth that our Ance≈øtors had a reuerend opinion of the Pope long after S. Gregory for S. Gregories ≈øake. To the≈øe Catholicks I will ad al≈øo the verdict of a few Prote≈øtants.Prote≈øtaÃÑts. D VVhitaker. D. Whitaker cont. Dur. p. 397. ≈øaith: He was a learned and holy Bishop and p. 502. I confe≈ø≈øe Gregory to haue bene a good and holy man. Godvvin. Godwin in vita Augu≈øt. a good man that ble≈ø≈øed and holy Father Gregory. Item This good man being made Pope tooke e≈øpeciall care of ≈øending Preachers into this Land. D. Sutclif Subuer≈ø. c. 2.D. Sutclif. Gregory and Eleutherius were Bishops, and famous men in the Church for their painful labors, and con≈øtancy in teaching the
truth. Bale cent. 1. c. 68. ≈øaith he was the excellent of all the Bishops of Rome for learning and life. That again≈øt his will and ≈øtriuing to the contrary, and at last compelled, he ≈øucceded Pope Pelagius. That he was a learned, and good man, founded ho≈øpitals, inuited pilgrims to his table, ≈øent things nece≈ø≈øary to the Monks of Hieru≈øalem, and maintained three thou≈øand Virgins. And c. 7 He reduced the Goths from Ariani≈øme to the Church, profe≈ø≈øed him≈øelfe by writing the Seruant of Gods ≈øeruants, that therby he might appeare mo≈øt far from all ambition, and de≈øire of command. Bell in his Wofull Cry p. 62. ≈øaith:Bel. Gregory was a holy Bishop indeed. And in his Suruey p. 156. He was vertuous and learned. pag. 480.D Humfrey. Luth, Gal. 4 I tink Greg vvas loued. c. 5. the vvorld hath in admiration the holines of Gregory. A man of ≈øufficient credit. Willet in his Synop≈øis, A modest and humble Bishop. D. Humfrey, Ie≈øuiti≈ømi part. 2. pag. 624. Gregory ≈øurnamed Great, and indeed great, a great man, and indued with many vertues of deuine grace. Thus Prote≈øtants account of ≈øaint Au≈øtins Mai≈øter.

2. As for S. Au≈øtin him≈øelf, Godwin in Aug. ≈øaith: He was a man of exceeding tall ≈øtature, well fauoured, S. Au≈øtins vertuous deeds. and of a very amiable countenance. And as for his great holines it appeareth many wayes. For fir≈øt, being very yonge, he for≈øooke all the plea≈øures and commodities of the world, and became a Monk, entering into S. Gregories mona≈øtery, which no doubt was a Nur≈øerie of

Where, (as Greg. ≈øaith ex Beda lib. 1. c. 27.) he was brought vp from his youth in regular di≈øcipline, and according to his rule imitated the forme, and rule v≈øed in the Primitiue Church of the Fathers, among whome all things were common. where he ≈øo exceeded in vertue as he was made Superior ouer the Mona≈øtery. ex Greg. lib. 7. epi≈øt. 112. Secondly, at Saint Gregories commandement he left his owne Contry, where he ≈øerued God in quietnes, and came to preach the Go≈øpell both ≈øo far of as our Contry is from Rome, & to ≈øuch barbarous people, as our Nation then was. Thirdly, after he entred into England, he liued ≈øo vertuou≈øly, that albeit he prooued, no doubt, his doctrine by great learning, and confirmed it (as ≈øhalbe ≈øhewed hereafter) by many and great miracles, yet as ≈øaint Beda affirmeth lib. 1. c. 26. our Contry was conuerted more by the holines of him, and his fellowes liues, than by any other meanes.See Hunting. lib. 3. After they were now entred (≈øaith Beda lib. cit.) into their lodging they began to exerci≈øe the Apo≈øtolick order of liuing of the primitiue Church, S. Au≈øtins and his fellovves Apo≈øtolick life. ≈øeruing God in continuall prayer, watching, and fa≈øting, and preaching the word of life to as many as they could, de≈øpi≈øing the commodities of the world as things none of their owne, taking of them onely whome they in≈øtructed ≈øo much as might ≈øerue their nece≈øsities, liuing them ≈øelues
according to that they taught other, and being redy to ≈øuffer both troubles and death it ≈øelf in defen≈øe of the truth they taught. VVherby many did beleeue and were baptized, marueling much at the ≈øimplicitie of their innocent liuing, and at the ≈øweetnes of their heauenly doctryn. Infr√†. The King him ≈øelf being much delighted with the puritie of their life, and the example of their godly conuer≈øation, as al≈øo with their ≈øweete promi≈øes, which to be true they prooued with many miracles did beleeue, and was baptized. VVhat paines he tooke fir≈øt in per≈øuading our Nation the Chri≈øtian faith, which was then addicted to Idolatrie, after in in≈øtructing them, who were ≈øo rude and ignorant in all faith, and la≈øtly in baptizing, and admini≈øtring the ≈øacraments hauing ≈øome times to Chri≈øten ten thou≈øand at a tyme, none can expre≈ø≈øe. Capgraue in his life ≈øaith, he went trough England on foote preaching,
S. Au≈øtins paines and frequent praier.
Had the gift of miracles and of Prophecie. and mo≈øt coÃÑ monly barefoote, and had callum in genibus by frequency of prayers. Much paines al≈øo he tooke vvith the VVelch men in two Councels, & be≈øides di≈øputation wrought miracles in their ≈øight. He had the gift of miracles ex Greg. apud Bedam lib. 1. c. 31. And of Prophecie, Beda lib. 2. c. 2. This briefly was the admirable and Apo≈øtolick holines of life of Saint Au≈øtin and his fellowes, which no doubt he coÃÑcluded with a happie death. For his Epitaph recorded by
S. Beda lib. 2. c. 3. witne≈ø≈øeth after he had conuerted King Ethelbert and his people to the faith of Christ, fulfilling in peace the dayes of his office, died the 26. of May.

Vvitne≈ø≈øes of S. Au≈øtins holines. S. Gregor.4. Thirdly, for the witne≈ø≈øe of tho≈øe, that liued with S. Au≈øtin. Fir≈øt is S. Gregory him≈øelf, who be≈øt knew him, and was be≈øt able to iudg of his vertue. He writing to King Ethelbert in Beda lib. 1. c. 32. ≈øaith, that S. Au≈øtin had bene brought vp in the rule of Religion, and was by the grace of God of much vertue. And lib. 9. epist. 58. writing to S. Gregory,Diuers other Popes he is highly commended: Of Pope Boniface 4. in Malmsbury lib. 1. Pont. p. 208. he is called the holy Doctor: Of Pope Honorius ibidem p. 209. Au≈øtin of holy remembrance. 5. Fourthly,Vvitne≈ø≈øes of S. La≈øtly, for the confe≈øsion of Prote≈øtants, Fox in his Acts pag. 105. ≈øaith of Saint Au≈øtin and his fellowes thus: At length when the King had well con≈øidered the hone≈øt conuer≈øation of their life, and mooued with their miracles, wrought through Gods hands by them, he heard them more gladly and la≈øtly by their hol≈øom exhortations and example of godly life, he was by them conuerted and chri≈øtened in the yeare

div.head: CHAP. VI. Certain ≈ølanders impo≈øed vpon Saint Austin, di≈øprooued.
div.p:
CIcero, in his Oration for Ro≈øcius, ≈øaith: that as fier falling into water is ≈øtraight put out: ≈øo a ≈ølander put vpon an innocent man, is quickly extingui≈øhed. But this is an impudent ≈ølander, deui≈øed fir≈øt (for any thing that I can finde) by Bale, who centur. 1. capit. 70.Bale ≈ølandereth S. Au≈øtin vpon reports. fearfully broached it, and therfor referreth it to reports, ≈øaying: Vt ferunt, as ≈øome reporte. But afterward Cent. 13. cap. 1. he confidently auoucheth it. After him tooke vp that ≈ølander Iuell Defen≈ø. Apolog. part. 5. Abbots
in his An≈øwer to Do. Bi≈øhop, p. 198. Sutclif Subuer≈ø. c. 3. & 7. and others.

That S. Au≈øtin vvas no cau≈øe of the death of the British MoÃÑks.This fal≈øe ≈ølander is many wayes refuted. Fir≈øt, becau≈øe it is auouched without all te≈øtimonies of antiquity. Bale (as I ≈øay) hauing no one to name before, referreth him ≈øelfe to vncertain reports, if he be not both Author, and reporter too. Abbots citeth Iuell, Sutclif, alleageth Thomas Grey, & a nameles Chronicle which he calleth ould, as if they ≈øhould haue ≈øaid, ask my fellow if I be a theefe. Secondly, becau≈øe the Britons albeit enemyes to Saint Au≈øtin, blamed not him, but others, for this ≈ølaughter, as is euident in Galfrid lib. 4. cap. 4. Thirdly, becau≈øe the ≈ølanderers of Saint Au≈øtin di≈øagree in their tale more than the accu≈øers of Su≈øanna, and therfor if Daniel might be iudge, the≈øe would be condemned as well as they were. For ≈øome ≈øay S. Au≈øtin excited King Ethelfrid to this murder, others ≈øay, not Saint Au≈øtin but K. Ethelbert his ≈øcoller: Some ≈øay, that Ethelfrid made this ≈ølaughter: others, that K. Ethelbert, as Grey cited by Sutclif. So they agree nether in the Author nor Actor of this matter. Fourthly becau≈øe as Beda te≈øtifieth lib. 2. c. 2. Saint Au≈øtin was long before that ≈ølaughter, taken out of this life to the Kingdom of heauen, and no way cau≈øed it but rather forwarned

And the ≈øame te≈øtifie our be≈øt Hi≈øtoriographers both Catholicks and Prote≈øtants. Namely Malmesbury lib. 3. Reg. pag. 325 Hunting. lib. 3. Florent. an. 603. We≈øtmon. an. 603. 2. To this Sutclif cap. 7. cit. an≈øwereth,Sutclif feigneth corruption in S. Beda. that tho≈øe words of Saint Beda touching Saint Au≈øtins death before the ≈ølaughter, are added by ≈øome forger. Au≈øtin died. ether an. 614. as Malmesbury ≈øaith in Hi≈øt. and in Fa≈øtis; or an. 605. as Sigebert ≈øaith in Chron. or 608. as Bale hath cent. 13. cap. 1. or an. 604. as Baron. gathereth out of Beda, and Florent. in Chron. and Stow pag. 62. affirmeth. div.head: CHAP. VII. That S. Au≈øtin was mooued with holy motiues to come to preach to our Nation.
div.p:
ALthough what can be ≈øaid of this matter, will be clear inough, partly by what hath bene already ≈øaid, partly by what ≈øhall hereafter: yet becau≈øe it helpeth much to the perfect iudgmeÃÑt of religions, to know what mooued the fir≈øt Authors & Founders of theÃÑ in any CoÃÑtry to preach & publi≈øh them, for therby they may iudg of their ≈øincerity or fraudulent meaning, and whether they ≈øeeke the glory of God, and ≈øaluation of the CoÃÑtry, or their owne good: Therfore I will declare now what motiues Saint Au≈øtin had to teach vs his
religion, and afterward, in the Second Booke, what motiues likewi≈øe Luther had to teach vs his. Fir≈øt therfore, Saint Au≈øtin could not be mooued by that proper motiue or ≈øpur of all Archereticks or Sect-mai≈øters to abducere di≈øcipulos (as the Apo≈øtle ≈øaith of them) post ≈øe: Vaine glorie moued not. S. Au≈øtin. that is to be the head and founder of a Sect, becau≈øe (as ≈øhalbe ≈øhewed anon) his religion was the v≈øuall and common religion of all Chri≈øtendome in his tyme. Secondly, he could no be mooued in hope of honor,Nor honor. for in Rome he was head of his mona≈øtery, & in England among a fierce, ≈øtrange & barbarous Nation, he could expect none. Wherfore albeit (beyond all humaine expectatioÃÑ) he was made Archbi≈øhop, yet hauing no hope therof, that can not be iu≈øtly thought to haue moued him to vndertake that voyage. Thirdly, profit could not moue him to this enterpri≈øe. For what profit could he expect here, or what profit did he expect, who (as Saint Beda lib. 1.Nor profit cap. 26. ≈øaith of him and his fellowes) de≈øpi≈øed the commodities of this world as things none of their owne, taking of them whome they in≈øtructed, onely ≈øo much as might ≈øerue their nece≈øsities. And being made Archbi≈øhop did according as Saint Gregory appointed him in Beda lib, 1. cap. 27. liue according to his religious rule, not a part from his Clergie,
but followed that trade and forme of liuing which was v≈øed in the primitiue Church among the Fathers, among whome there was none that ≈øaid that to be his owne, which he po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed, but all things were comon.

2 And as for worldly plea≈øur what ≈øhould moue Saint Au≈øtin (think we) to leaue his natiue Contry,Nor plea≈øure. and to ≈øeeke plea≈øure in a ≈øtrange Contry, where he knoweth nether place, per≈øon nor language? Or what plea≈øure did Saint Au≈øtin ≈øeeke here who with his fellowes liued here ≈øo Angel like, that as Saint Beda writteth lib. 1. cap. 26. our Nation maruailed much at their ≈øimplicity, of their innocent liuing, and our King was then much delighted with the puritie of their life and the example of their godly conuer≈øation. And being Archbi≈øhop, yet left not his religious life, and as is before ≈øhewed, tooke exceeding paines in teaching, and baptizing our Nation, and wonderfully labored to conuert the Britons al≈øo. Who (as is before ≈øaid) went ≈øtill on foote, and for the mo≈øt part barefoote, and had his
knees hard like the knees of a camell by continuall prayer.Motiues of S. Au≈øtins preaching Wherfore no human motiue, but the diuine motiues of obedience to his Mai≈øter and lawfull Bi≈øhop the great Saint and glorious Doctor of Gods Church Saint Gregory,ObedieÃÑce. who ≈øent him and commanded him to come hither to preach. And of Charitie,Charitie to ≈øaue our Nations ≈øoules, by bringing them out of heatheni≈øh infidelitie to the faith of Chri≈øt.Gods glorie. And glorie of God were the incitements, motiues and cau≈øes of Saint Au≈øtins comming hither, and preaching that religion which he did. And this is manife≈øt both by the te≈øtimonies of Catholick Writers and confe≈øsions of Prote≈øtants which we cited before touching Saint Au≈øtins holines, and ≈øhall alleadge in this next Chapter where we ≈øhall prooue that this great Clerck and holy man Saint Au≈øtin moued by the≈øe ≈øaintly motiues to preach to our Nation, was al≈øo lawfully ≈øent therto with ≈øufficient authoritie and commi≈øsion.

div.head: CHAPT. VIII. That Saint Au≈øtin was lawfully ≈øent hither to preach, prooued by diuers authorities and confe≈øsion of Prote≈øtants.
div.p:
TWO things ther are required to euery lawfull Pa≈øtor, to wit, both right Orders, and lawfull Commi≈øsion to admini≈øter the Sacraments and Word of God. And albeit by order of doctrine, wee ≈øhould ≈øpeake fir≈øt of Saint Au≈øtins orders, yet becau≈øe his Commi≈øsion being cleared, his orders will ea≈øely appeare to be good, I will ≈øpeake fir≈øt of his CoÃÑmi≈ø≈øion where with he was ≈øent to preach. And that he was ≈øent of Saint Gregory, wee need not prooue. For as Sutclif ≈øaith in his Subuer≈øion cap. 3. It is not denied, that Gregory ≈øent Au≈øtin. The onely difficulty can be whether he were lawfully ≈øent, and by ≈øufficient authoritie or no.Hovv manie vvayes S: Au≈øtins mi≈øsion is prooued. But that he was lawfully ≈øent to preach I will prooue fir≈øt by ≈øacred te≈øtimony from Heauen; Secondly, by authority of Catholicks; Thirdly, by confe≈øsion of Prote≈øtants; Fourthly, by examples; and la≈øtly by rea≈øon.
The te≈øtimony from Heauen is of Saint Peter,By S Peters te≈øtimonie from heauen. who appearing in a vi≈øion to Saint Laurence ≈øucce≈ø≈øor of Saint Au≈øtin, when he vpon the reuolt of our Contrie to Pagani≈øme intended to abandon the Land, ≈øcourged him (≈øaith Saint Beda lib. 2. cap. 6.) with ≈øharp ≈øtripes a great while in the clo≈øe night, and asked why he would for≈øake the flock which he him ≈øelf had committed vnto him. Behould Saint Peter from Heauen te≈øtifieth that he had coÃÑmitted English men to the teaching of Saint Laurence, one of Saint Au≈øtins fellow labourers, & whome Saint Au≈øtin him ≈øelf appointed & con≈øecrated for his ≈øucce≈ø≈øor. And when Saint Laurence awaked (≈øaith Godwin) he found it more than a dreame, for all his body was gore blood. And therfore I will for breuity omitt their te≈øtimonies, and content my ≈øelf with the≈øe mens confe≈øsions. The learned and ancient Fathers (≈øaith Bil≈øon lib. of Obedience pag. 143.) call the Bishops of Rome Peters ≈øucce≈ø≈øors. pag. 380. Saint Peter founder of Saint Leo his Church. The Fathers ≈øay (writeth Reinolds pag. 218. 219). Peter was Bi≈øhop of Rome, and he nameth Hierom, Eu≈øeb. Irenaeus. Bi≈øhop Cooper in Chron. Linus fir≈øt Bishop of Rome after Peter. But ≈øaith Reinol. they meant improperly. And why ≈øo? Becau≈øe (≈øaith he) Peter being Apo≈øtle could not be Bi≈øhop of one Cyttie.VVheÃÑ the Fathers call Peter Bishop of Rome they meane properly. SecoÃÑdly, becau≈øe Irenaeus lib. 3. c. 3. nameth Linus fir≈øt Bi≈øhop of Rome, and Eu≈øebius in Chron. calleth Euodius fir≈øt Bi≈øhop of Antioch, which could not be if Peter had bene a proper Bi≈øhop. But again≈øt the≈øe cauils
I oppo≈øe the propriety of the word Bishop, which no Father or ancient writer hath ≈øignified that he v≈øed improperly when he called S. Peter Bi≈øhop: And all words (e≈øpecially in hi≈øtories) are to be taken properly, when the Authors declare not the contrary, els we ≈øhould neuer be ≈øure how we ≈øhould vnder≈øtaÃÑd the writer. SecoÃÑdly, they ≈øay, that S. Peter was fir≈øt B. of Rome. Negare non potes (≈øaith. Optatus l. 2. writing again≈øt hereticks) Thou can≈øt not deny that thou knowe≈øt, that to Peter fir≈øt was an Epi≈øcopal Chaire ≈øet in Rome in which fir≈øt ≈øate Peter, to whome ≈øucceded Linus. Loe how certain was it theÃÑ that the very hereticks could not deny, but they knew it to be ≈øo. Wherfor I ask when the Fathers ≈øayd Peter was fir≈øt Bi≈øhop, how they v≈øed the word Bishop? If improperly, then they meant ≈øo of Linus. If properly, theÃÑ we haue our purpo≈øe. Thirdly, in reckoning of the Catalogue of the Bi≈øhops of Rome, they alwaies name Peter fir≈øt. Iren l. 3. c. 3. Eu≈øeb. Chron. Epiph. haer. 27. Hier. in Clemente, Optatus l. 2. Aug. ep. 165. But what ≈øhould he do in the Catalogue of proper Bi≈øhops, if he were none him ≈øelf? Be≈øides they reckon him fir≈øt Bi≈øhop of Rome as they reckon Mark fir≈øt B. of Alexandria, but Mark was a proper Bi≈øhop. Fourthly, they call the See of Rome the ≈øeat or
chaire of Peter, S. Cyprian lib. 1. Epi≈øt 3. lib. 4. epi≈øt. 2. S. Hierom in Pet. ep. ad Dama≈øum Aug. lib. 2. cont. Petil, cap. 51. Sozom. lib. 1. c. 14. Pro≈øper lib. De ingratis Bernard epi≈øt. 237. And in like ≈øort they call it ≈øedes Apo≈øtolica as Caluin confe≈ø≈øeth, and is euident ex Concil. Calcedon. Act. 16. And Rein. Confer. pag. 369. The Fathers in ≈øpeaking of the Church of Rome mention often the Chair, and ≈øeat of Peter. Hierom honoreth the Bishop of that See with the name of Peters Chaire. Fiftly, they call the Bi≈øhop of Rome ≈øucce≈ø≈øor to S. Peter. S. Hier. ep. ad Dama≈ø. Concil. Ephe≈ø. 1. Tom. 2. S. Eulog. apud Greg. lib. 6. ep. 37. And that they meane of a proper ≈øucce≈ø≈øor, appeareth by that they attribute that peculierly to the Pope. Sixtly, & la≈øtly they ≈øay that Peter ≈øate in the Bi≈øhops Chaire of Rome as they ≈øaye his ≈øucce≈ø≈øors did. Cathedra (≈øaith S. Au≈øtin lib. 2. cont. Petil.) quid tibi fecit Romana in qua Petrus ≈øedit, & in qua nunc Ana≈øta≈øius ≈øedet? VVhat hath the Chair of Rome done to thee in which Peter ≈øate, and in which now ≈øitteth Ana≈øta≈øius? Therfore either Peter was a proper Bi≈øhop, or Ana≈øta≈øius was none. To conclude,Reinolds ≈øayth P. Dama≈ø. ≈øucceded Peter in his chaire. Reinolds him ≈øelf though vnawares confe≈ø≈øeth it pag. 376. where he ≈øayth that Dama≈øus ≈øucceded Peter as in Chair, ≈øo in doctrine.

10. As for the fir≈øt of Reinolds cauils. It is no more again≈øt Peters Apo≈øtle≈øhip to be
Bi≈øhop of one Citty, than it was to take a particuler care of the Iewes, as he did, nor more than it is for the Bi≈øhop of Win≈øter to be Par≈øon of Ea≈øtmean. And for the ≈øecond, Irenaeus doth not call Linus fir≈øt Bi≈øhop of Rome, but onely ≈øaith that Peter, and Paul gaue him the Bi≈øhoprick to gouern the Church, to wit vnder Peter, and in his ab≈øence. Eu≈øeb. indeed calleth Euodius fir≈øt Bi≈øhop of Antioch, but that he meaneth of pure Bi≈øhops which were not al≈øo Apo≈øtles. For before he had ≈øayd Petrus Eccle≈øiam Antiochenam fundauit, √≤bique Cathedram adeptus, ≈øedit. And Rein. loco cit. confe≈ø≈øeth, and both he, and all graunt that Linus was Peters ≈øucce≈ø≈øor. And as for Ruffin, his words proue no more, but that Peter in≈øtituted Linus to help him, e≈øpecially in his ab≈øence, as Valerius did in≈øtitute S. Aug. in his life tyme, who after his death ≈øucceeded him, and ≈øo did Linus to Peter. Thus haue I prooued that S. Gregorie was ≈øucce≈ø≈øor to S. Peter in his Epi≈øcopall See, and that he ≈øucceded him al≈øo in faith I neede not proue, becau≈øe prote≈øtants, although they find ≈øome fault with Greg. doctrine, yet they confe≈ø≈øe (as is ≈øhewed before) that he taught as much as is needfull to ≈øaluation, and con≈øequently he wanted no thing to true ≈øucce≈øsion to S. Peter.

11. Fourthly I proue that the Pope was mo≈øt likely, to ≈øuccede Saint Peter,Proued out of Fathers that the P. ≈øuccedeth peter in his authority. by that which the Fathers attribute to him. Saint Hierom epi≈øt. ad Dama≈øum de nomine hypo≈øta≈øis. Ego nullum primum, ni≈øi Chri≈øtum ≈øequens beatitudini tuae, id e≈øt, Cathedrae Petri communione con≈øocior, ≈øuper illam Petram aedificatam Eccle≈øiam ≈øcio. Quicunque extra hanc domum agnum comederit prophanus e≈øt. I following none formo≈øt but Chri≈øt, communicate with thy Holines, that is with the Chaire of Peter. Vpon that Rock do I know the Church was built, who ≈øoeuer ≈øhall eate the lambe out of this hou≈øe is prophane. Note how he ≈øaith, that he followeth fir≈øt Chri≈øt, and next the Pope, and that the rea≈øon, which he giueth herof after, was not why he followed Chri≈øt fir≈øt, for that were needles to proue among≈øt Chri≈øtians; And if he would haue giuen any, it would haue bene,Hierom follovveth the P. next after chri≈øt becau≈øe Chri≈øt made the P. the rock of his Church. becau≈øe Chri≈øt is God; But the rea≈øon which he giueth, was why he followed the Pope next to Chri≈øt, to wit, becau≈øe he knew him to be the Rock, on which the Church was built. Wherby it is euident, that by the Rock, he meant not Chri≈øt, as Bil≈øon lib. de Obed. pag 87. and others would, but Pope Dama≈øus as Reinolds coÃÑfe≈ø≈øeth p. 370. 376. But yet he meant not (≈øaith Reinolds) the ≈øucce≈øsion of the Popes, becau≈øe Hierom writeth that Pope Liberius had before
≈øub≈øcribed to Ariani≈øme. But if Hieroms words be well poÃÑdered he will be found to haue ≈øaid, both that Pope Dama≈øus was the Rock, and that his ≈øucce≈øsion to Saint Peter in his Chaire of Rome, was the cau≈øe why he was the Rock. For if a ≈øubiect writing to the King ≈øhould ≈øay: Nullum primum ni≈øi Deum ≈øequens maiestati tuae, id est, Throno Conque≈øtoris (in temporalibus) con≈øocior. Super illam petram aedificatum Angliae Regnum ≈øcio. Quicumque extra hanc domum aliquid egerit, rebellis est. He ≈øhould confe≈ø≈øe that both the King were head of the Realme, and with all tell how he came by that authority, to witt, by ≈øucce≈øsion to the conqueror. So Saint Hierome in the for≈øaid words both ≈øayd that Pope Dama≈øus per≈øon, which he meant by Beatitudini tuae, was the Rock on which in his tyme, the Church was built: and ≈øayd with all that his per≈øon had that authoriry by his ≈øucce≈øsion to Saint Peter in his Roman Chaire, and therfore added the≈øe words, id e≈øt, Cathedrae Petri, as a further explication of the former. And con≈øequently he meant that the Church is built vpon all Popes that lawfully ≈øucceed in the Chaire of Peter. Which is ≈øo euident as Doct. Feild lib. 1. de Eccle≈øia‚ñ™
D. Feild. cap. 41. confe≈ø≈øeth plainly that Saint Hierome loc cit. ≈øaid, that Peters Chaire is the Rock the Church is builded vpon. As for Reinolds
rea≈øons, were it truth that S. Hierome wrote (as Reinolds ≈øaith) of Liberius, which yet diuers deny, and Reinolds mu≈øt deny, if he will ≈øpeak agreably to him ≈øelf. For pag. 570. he ≈øaith, that the words of Au≈øtin (ep. cont. Donat. and Hierome ep. cit.) do import a ≈øincerity of faith in the Roman Bishops to their tyme, which would not be true, if Liberius had fallen. But admit I ≈øay it were true, that Liberius had denyed his faith, that maketh no more again≈øt his Rock ≈øhip, than the like fault in S. Peter did again≈øt his. For as S. Peter though he denyed his faith, yet taught not infidelitie as he was Apo≈øtle, and Pa≈øtor of the Church, ≈øo nether Liberius though he committed a per≈øonall crime, yet taught he no here≈øie, as ≈øucce≈ø≈øor to S. Peter, in which ≈øorte onely he is the Rock of the Church.

12. Secondly, S. Au≈øtin ep. contra Donat. ≈øaith:S. Au≈øtin. Numerate Sacerdotes vel ab ip≈øa Petri Sede. Ip≈øa est enim Petra quam non vincunt ≈øuperbae inferorum portae: Number the Priests euen from the very Seat of Peter; Succe≈øsioÃÑ of Popes by S. Au≈øtin the Rock of the Church. It is the Rock which the proud gates of hell do not ouercom. Behould how the very ≈øucce≈øsion of Popes from Peter, is called the Rock of the Church, as the Chair of Peter was before called of S. Hierome. To this Bil≈øon pag. 88. Fir≈øt ≈øaith that the text is corrupted, and that it ≈øhould be ip≈øe
and referred to Peters per≈øon. But this is a mere ≈øurmi≈øe refelled in all the copies in Europe. Secondly he ≈øaith, that though it be ip≈øa, and grammatically agree with the ≈øub≈øtantiue Petra, which followeth, yet it may be meant of Peters per≈øon. But if Saint Au≈øtin had meant that Peter alone had bene the Rock, and that his ≈øucce≈ø≈øors partaked nothing with him in that, he would neuer haue byd vs number his ≈øucce≈ø≈øors too, and then tell vs that that was the Rock. Wherfore Reynolds Confer. pag. 384. confe≈ø≈øeth that Saint Au≈øtin applyed this text the gates of hell, &c. to the Church of Rome. And Bil≈øon him≈øelf as doubting of either of the former an≈øwers ≈øaith thirdly, that Saint Au≈øtin ≈øaid not that Peters Seat is the Rock of the Church, but that hell gates preuaile not again≈øt it. But to our purpo≈øe all is one, that in Saint Au≈øtins iudgment Peters Seat (that is Peters ≈øucce≈ø≈øors in Seat) are either the Rock of the church,Theodoret. or ≈øo ≈øurely founded theron, as the gates of hell ≈øhall not preuaile again≈øt theÃÑ.

13. Thirdly, Theodoret an ancient and Grecian Doctor writing to Renatus, ≈øaith of the Roman See: Tenet enim ≈øancta Sedes gubernacula regendarum cuncti orbis Eccle≈øiarum. That holy ≈øeat hath the gouernment of all the Churches of the world. Which words are ≈øo plaine, as Iuell Art. 4. Diu. 21. findeth no
better an≈øwer than (iudging others by his owne humor) to ≈øay, That man naturally aduanceth his power at who≈øe hands he ≈øeeketh help. As if Theodoret were ≈øuch a man as would giue an Antichri≈øtian title (for ≈øo Prote≈øtants acount the gouernment of the Churches in the world) or S. Leo accept it for flatery. Finally the great Councel of Galcedon ep. ad Leonem, calleth Pope Leo their head, and ≈øay that to him.Concil. Galcedon. Vineae cu≈øtodia a Domino commi≈ø≈øa e≈øt. The cu≈øtodie of the Vinyard (that is the Church) was committed by our Lorde. And thus I hope I haue ≈øufficiently proued both by reuelation from heauen, by the authoritie of the Church then aliue, and ≈øince, by the examples of Popes euer ≈øince S. Peters tyme bv confe≈ø≈øion of Prote≈øtants, and finally by rea≈øon taken out of ≈øcripture, that S. Greg. had lawful authoritie to ≈øend S. Au≈øtin. Now let vs come to S. Au≈øtins orders.

div.head: CHAP. X. That S. Au≈øtin was rightly ordered to admini≈øter the Sacraments, and preach the word of God.
div.p:
1. THat S. Augu≈øtin was created Prie≈øt at Rome is euident by his ≈øaying Ma≈ø≈øe, preaching, and Chri≈øtening as ≈øoone as he came to Canterburie, as is before rehear≈øed out of Beda lib. 1. cap. 26. And after he had conuerted King Ethelbert he came (≈øaith Beda cap. 27.) to Arles, where of Etherius Archbishop of that Citty he was con≈øecrated Archbishop of the Nation of Englishmen; according as S. Greg. the Pope had commanded. And the King (≈øaith the ≈øame S. Beda cap. 26.) gaue him place for his See in the Citty of Canterburie. Here by the way I note, that wheras S. Greg. lib. 7. epi≈øt. 30. ≈øaith, that S. Au≈øtin was created Bi≈øhop a GermaniaruÃÑ Epi≈øcopis, he doth not gain-≈øay S. Beda, who ≈øaith he was created by the Bi≈øhop of Arles, becau≈øe France was of the writers of that tyme called Germanie, as appeareth by Venantius Fortunatus in Carmine de Nuptijs Sigeberti & Brunechildae, which might be,
partly becau≈øe the French at that tyme and long after gouerned a great part of Germany, partly al≈øo becau≈øe the Francks who then ruled in France were Germans come out of Germanie. But to our purpo≈øe.That S. Au≈øtin vvas rightly ordered. That S. Au≈øtin was rightly created Prie≈øt appeareth, by that he was made by the authoritie of S. Gregory, or his predece≈ø≈øors, whome prote≈øtants account to haue bene true Bi≈øhops of Rome. And Doct. Reinolds Confer. pag. 362. acknowledgeth the Pope to haue yet Bi≈øhoply power ouer his owne Dioce≈ø≈øe. S. Au≈øtin therfore being a Roman, and made by the Bi≈øhoply authoritie of the Pope, was rightly made Prie≈øt. And in lyke ≈øort it may be proued that he was rightly con≈øecrated a Bi≈øhop. For he was made by the authoritie of the Pope with the con≈øent of the King of England. Secondly I proue that S. Au≈øtin was lawfully con≈øecrated Bi≈øhop by the con≈øent of the Chri≈øtian world. For S. Greg. commanded him to be made Bi≈øhop, the French Bi≈øhops made him, the Engli≈øh Chri≈øtians receaued him, and the Ea≈øt Church, to whome S. Greg. wrote of the matter, neuer di≈øliked him, and all the Chri≈øtian world hitherto hath approued him. Nether did the Britons (though enemyes) take any exceptions again≈øt his orders. Thirdly becau≈øe all
prote≈øtants call S. Au≈øtin a Bi≈øhop, and number him fir≈øt in the Catalogue of the Archbi≈øhops of Canterburie. And if their Bi≈øhops and Mini≈øters will haue any orders at all, they mu≈øt confe≈ø≈øe that S. Au≈øtins orders were good, and ≈øufficient. For as Doct. Feild ≈øaith, lib. 3. of the Church cap. 39. In England they which had bene Bishops in the former corrupt ≈øtate of the Church (≈øo he termeth Catholick tymes) did ordaine Bishops and Mini≈øters. And Sutclif. an≈øwer to exceptions pag. 88. ≈øaith. Couerdal and Scory (who were Bi≈øhops in King Edwards tyme) layd hands vpon Bishop Parker. Bel in his Funerall profe≈ø≈øeth openly that he hath not departed from the ≈øub≈øtance of his Popi≈øh orders, but onely from the ceremonies therof. Be≈øides, euident it is, that what Bi≈øhop or Prie≈øt ≈øo euer had bene made in King Henries tyme, was neuer con≈øecrate a new in King Edwards dayes. Who had bene made in Queene Maries dayes was acounted to haue ≈øufficient orders in Queene Eli≈øabeths Reigne. And yet what Prie≈øt apo≈øtateth from his faith is, without more orders, thought to haue orders ynough fore mini≈øtring the Sacraments and vvord of God, or prote≈øtants haue no order at all. And thus hauing ≈øhewed that S. Au≈øtin was the fir≈øt Preacher of Chri≈øtian fayth to our
Engli≈øh Nation, and that he had both ≈øufficient learning and vertue to di≈øcharge ≈øuch a function, and withall lawfull commi≈øsion and right orders to admini≈øter the Sacraments, and preach the word of God; now let vs ≈øee what kind of faith and religion it was, which he preached; and fir≈øt what kind in generall, and afterward what it was in particuler.

div.head: CHAP. XI. That the Faith which Saint Au≈øtin preached to our English Ance≈øtors, was the vniuer≈øall Faith of Chri≈øtendome at that tyme.
div.p:
1. THis I proue fir≈øt by the te≈øtimony of tho≈øe that liued in that tyme,S. Au≈øtins vniuer≈øal religion proued by S. Greg. among whome the cheefe≈øt and principal is S. Gregory him ≈øelfe, who hauing bene long tyme the Popes Legat in Con≈øtantinople, and after being Pope and receauing letters from all partes of Chri≈øtendome, could not be ignorant what was the vniuer≈øal faith of Ea≈øt, We≈øt, and of all Chri≈øtendome at that time. He I ≈øay
writing to S. Au≈øtin. lib. 9. Epi≈øt. 58. hath the≈øe words.f All the aithful of S. Au≈øtins time ioyed at our Nations conuer≈øion by him. Quis ≈øufficiat, &c. VVho can tel what ioy aro≈øe in the harts of all the faithfull that the English nation by the working of Almighty God his grace, and the labor of thy brotherhood, hauing ca≈øt away the darknes of errors, is endued with the light of the holy faith, that with ≈øincere deuotion it trampleth the Idolls to which before vvith mad feare it bowed vnto, that with a pure hart it is ≈øubiect to Almightie God. Behould S. Greg. witne≈ø≈øeth that all faithfull of that time acknowledged and reioyced that Au≈øtin brought the faith to our Engli≈øh Nation, and that they by his meanes ≈øerued God with mo≈øt ≈øincere deuotion and pure harts. But yet more plainly auoucheth he this truth, Moral. 27. cap. 6. Where glorying in God of the conuer≈øion of England he writeth thus.S. Au≈øtins doctrine the faith of Chri≈øtendom from the Ea≈øt to the vve≈øt. Behould now the faith hath entred the harts almo≈øt of all Nations. Behould God hath ioyned the bounds of the Ea≈øt and we≈øt in one faith. Behould the tonge of Britanie which knew nothing but to roare rudely, of late hath begun in Gods prai≈øes to ≈øound out the hebrew Alleluia. O mo≈øt comfortable ≈øpeach to all tho≈øe that follow S. Gregory and S. Au≈øtins doctrine,Great comfort for Catholicks. to heare auouched by irrefragable te≈øtimonie that it was the faith of the Church of God from the Ea≈øt to the we≈øt aboue a thou≈øand yeares agoe. For as Tertullian ≈øaith. Admit that God had neglected
his Church, and permitted it to run into errors, is it lykly that ≈øo many and ≈øo great Churches would con≈øpire wholy in error? No ≈øurely.

2. The next is S. Au≈øtin him ≈øelf who in Beda lib. 2. cap‚ñ™ 2. ≈øaith thus vnto the Britons.S. Au≈øtins. Doctrine proued to be vniuer≈øal by his ovvne te≈øtimonie Although in many other points yow do contrary to our cu≈øtome, or rather contrary to the cu≈øtome of the vniuer≈øall Church of Chri≈øt. Behould how he te≈øtifyeth his cu≈øtome to be the cu≈øtome of the vniuer≈øall Church of Chri≈øt in his tyme. And lib. 1. cap. 27. in his que≈øtions propo≈øed to S. Greg. he a≈øketh, VVhere there is but one faith, whie be there ≈øo many ≈øundry cu≈øtoms of Churches, and one cu≈øtome of Ma≈ø≈øes ob≈øerued at Rome, another in France? Here he manefe≈øtly te≈øtifyeth that there was but one faith and one ma≈ø≈øe in ≈øub≈øtance euery where, and the difference onely in ceremonies.S. Greg. communicated vvith all partes of Chri≈øtendom. The ≈øame al≈øo may be proued by the communion which S. Gregory (who≈øe faith was vndoubtedly the ≈øame with S. Au≈øtin) had with all Chri≈øtendom. For lib. 6. epi≈øt. 4. & 5. he communicateth with Cyriacus the Patriarch of Con≈øtantinople lib. 4. epi≈øt. 34. 36. lib. 7. epi≈øt. 30. he communicated with the Patriarch of Alexandria, and gloried to him of the conuer≈øion of England. lib. 1. epi≈øt. 25. lib. 4. epi≈øt. 37. lib. 6. epi≈øt. 24. lib. 7. epi≈øt. 3. 47. he communicated with the
Patriarch of Antioch; vnder which three Patriarchs was almo≈øt all the Ea≈øtern Church. And touching the We≈øtern Church lib. 1. epi≈øt. 4. lib. 4. epi≈øt. 46. He communicated with Leander Primat of Spaine. lib. 4. epi≈øt. 51. He communicated with Vigilius primate of France. lib. 9. epi≈øt. 61. he communicated with all the Catholick Bi≈øhops of Ireland. lib. 2. epi≈øt. 28. he communicated with all the Bi≈øhops of Italy. lib. 1. epi≈øt. 60. 61. he communicated with Ianuarius of Sardinia. lib. 1. epi≈øt. 68. he communicated with all the Bi≈øhops in Sicilie. lib. 1. epi≈øt. 76. with Leo Bi≈øhop of Cor≈øica lib. 1. epi≈øt. 75. with all the Bi≈øhops of Numidia. lib. 2. epi≈øt. 15. lib. 3. epi≈øt. 16. with all the Bi≈øhops of Dalmatia. lib. 3. epi≈øt. 37. He communicated with all the Bi≈øhop of Vizach, and epi≈øt. 30. With the Bi≈øhop of I≈øtria. And lib. 7. epi≈øt. 30. with the Bi≈øhops of Germanie, and con≈øequentlie with all Catholick Churches in the Ea≈øt and we≈øt.

S. vvilfrid auoucheth S. Au≈øtins doctrin to be vniuer≈øal.3. Of tho≈øe that liued after S. Au≈øtins tyme. Fir≈øt is S. Wilfrid Archbi≈øhop of York, who was borne ≈øoone after S. Au≈øtins death. For as S. Beda ≈øaith. lib. 5. cap. 20. He went vp to Rome in the tyme of Honorius Archbi≈øhop of Canterburie who was one of S. Au≈øtins fellowes, and he was as S. Beda ther writeth a worthie Prelat and notable Bishop. This man therfore in
Beda. lib. 3. cap. 25. di≈øputing with the Scotts for the Roman ob≈øeruation of Ea≈øter and ≈øhauen Crownes, ≈øaith thus, The Ea≈øter which we ob≈øerue we haue ≈øeene to haue bene in lyke maner ob≈øerued in Rome, in all Italie and France. This maner we know to be ob≈øerued in Africk. in Eegipt, in A≈øia, in Grece, and throughout all Nations and tongues of the world where the Church of Chri≈øt taketh place, be≈øides the≈øe few Scotts, and the Picts, and Britons, with whome the≈øe men do fondly contend again≈øt the whole world. Behould how S. Wilfrid auoucheth his Religion euen in that point wherein the Scotts then di≈ø≈øented from vs, to be the Religion of all the Chri≈øtian world. Nether did the Scotts, or could they deny it.S. Ceolfrid The next is S. Ceolfrid Abbot, and Mai≈øter to S. Beda, who liued in the ≈øame tyme, who writing to Naitan King of the Picts in Beda. lib. 5. cap. 22. and ≈øpeaking of his tyme ≈øaith: The whole Catholick Church agreeth in one faith, in one hope, and one charitie towards God. The third is S. Beda him ≈øelf who, lib. 2. cap. 2. ≈øaith,S. Beda. The Britons preferred their own Traditions before all other Churches, which throughout the whole world agreed with Au≈øtin in Chri≈øt. What I pray can be ≈øayd or imagined again≈øt the≈øe ≈øo manifould or irrefragable te≈øtimonies. Were S. Gregory, S. Au≈øtin, S. Wilfrid, S. Ceolfrid, S. Beda ignorant what was
the vniuer≈øall faith of Chri≈øtendome at that tyme? or were they ≈øo impudent as they would write, yea auouch to their aduer≈øaries face a knowne vntruth? No ≈øurely. And this truth Prote≈øtants al≈øo partly openly confe≈ø≈øe, partly tacitly grant and acknowledg. For Napier vpon the Reuelation of S. Iohn,See more infr. lib. 2. cap. 3. ≈øaith. Betwene the yeare of Chri≈øt 300. and 316. the Antichri≈øtian and Papi≈øticall Religion reigning vniuer≈øally without debatable contradiction 1260. yeares. And Brocard al≈øo vpon the Reuelation pag. 110. writeth that the Church (of Prote≈øtants) was troden downe and oppre≈ø≈øed by the Papacy euen from Silue≈øters tyme vnto the≈øe times. Bale cent. 1. pag. 69. ≈øaith. From this tyme (of Boniface 3. who ≈øucceeded S. Greg. with in a yeare or two) the puritie of heauenly doctrine vanished in the Church. pag. 65. After Greg. tyme puritie of doctrine perished, And 73. From Phocas who liued in S. Greg. tyme vvho (≈øaith he) begot the Papacy till the renewing of the Go≈øpel (by Luther) the doctrine of Chri≈øt was all the vvhile among Idiots in holes. Now if the heauenly doctrine of prote≈øtants peri≈øhed ≈øtraight after S. Greg. tyme, and euer ≈øince hath bene onely in Idiots, and lurking holes, how could it be the vniuer≈øall faith of all Chri≈øtendome in his tyme? Could the vniuer≈øall faith of Chri≈øtendome peri≈øh in one or two yeares? Would
all learned men, and open Churches for≈øake it in ≈øo ≈øhort time, and onely Idiots and holes keepe it? See more of this matter lib. 2. cap. 1. infra.

div.head: CHAP. XII. That the doctrine vvhich Au≈øtin taught vvas the true vvay to ≈øaluation. Proued by the open confe≈øsion of his Aduer≈øaries, and other things affirmed by them.
div.p:
1. THe fir≈øt aduer≈øaries which S. Au≈øtin had to his doctrine were the Britons before mentioned. Of whome S. Beda l. 2. cap. 2. writeth that S. Au≈øtin hauing cured a blind man whome they could not, The people prai≈øed S. Au≈øtin as a true preacher of all truth and veritie; Britons approue S. Au≈øtins doctrine. And the Britons confe≈ø≈øed indeed that they vnder≈øtood that to be the true way of righteou≈ønes, which Au≈øtin had preached, and ≈øhewed to them. The ≈øame writeth Huntington lib. 3. Au≈øtins doctrine. Yea if it be true that Godwin writeth in vit. Theod. That to him all the British Bishops, and generally all Britany yeelded obedience, and vnder him conformed them ≈øelues in all things to the rites and di≈øciplin of the Church of Rome, they performed this longe before, about 60. yeares after S. Au≈øtin.

Prote≈øtaÃÑts account S. Au≈øtins doctrin ≈øufficient to ≈øaluation.2. The next open Aduer≈øaries of Saint Au≈øtins doctrine in England haue bene the Prote≈øtants; Of whome, diuers haue in their writings openly acknowledged as much as the Britons did. For Iuel in his famous challeng,Iuel. offered to recant if any of the holy Fathers who liued in the fir≈øt 600. yeares after Chri≈øt were found contrarie to him in his Articles. In which compa≈ø≈øe of yeares both S. Greg. and S. Au≈øtin liued. And cryed out ≈øaying, O Gregorie, O Au≈øtin &c. If we be deceaued yow haue deceaued vs. Fulk. Fulk in 1. Cor. 15. Seeing Gregorie and Au≈øtin, (≈øaith he) taught the truth in all points nece≈ø≈øarie to ≈øaluation, our Contrie hath not beleeued in vaine, nor all our fore Fathers are dead in their ≈øinnes. Fox. Fox in his Acts pag. 111. 120. 122. Calleth the faith planted here by Au≈øtin and his fellow-laborers the Chri≈øtian

The true Religion of Chri≈øt. Godvvin. Apologie for the oath of alleageance, The faith of Chri≈øt. Godwin in Paulin. The Go≈øpel; And in Mellit. The faith of Chri≈øt. Holin≈øhed in Brit.Holinshead.
