Sutclif Subuer≈ø. cap. 3. termeth it Faith, Religion, Chri≈øtian Religion, Sutclif. and ≈øaith the people were conuerted to Chri≈øt, Finally Fox lib. 2. pag. 124. after he had tould in particuler how euery one of tho≈øe ≈øeauen Kingdoms which then were in England, was conuerted, concludeth thus;Fox. And thus by proce≈ø≈øe of tyme we haue di≈øcour≈øed from tyme to tyme, how and by what meanes the Idolatrous people were induced to the true fayth of Chri≈øt. And who con≈øidereth with him ≈øelfe, that not onely our Catholick Engli≈øh Ance≈øtors imbraced the doctrine of S. Au≈øtin, but al≈øo the erroneous Britons, and Prote≈øtants account it the true way of righteou≈ønes, the Go≈øpel, the Faith of Chri≈øt. The perfect faith of Chri≈øt, the right beleefe, the true
Religion of Chri≈øt, pure and incorrupt Chri≈øtianitie, and finally true faith of Chri≈øt, neede ≈øeeke no more, but what S. Au≈øtins faith was, and follow it. To tho≈øe that grant that S. Au≈øtins faith was the true way to ≈øaluaiion, I might adde al≈øo the Prote≈øtants, who affirme the ≈øame of the pre≈øent RomaÃÑ faith, who≈øe te≈øtimonies yow may ≈øee in the Apologie of Prote≈øtants Tract. 1. Sec. 6. Onely I will content my ≈øelfe with his Maie≈øties wordes to the parlament 9. of Nouember An. 1605. put forth in print thus: VVee do iu≈øtly confe≈ø≈øe that many Papi≈øts e≈øpecially our Forfathers laying their onely tru≈øt vpon Chri≈øt and his meritts (as they them ≈øelues teache in Bellarm.) may be and often tymes are ≈øaued, dete≈øtinge in that point and thinking the crueltie of Puritans worthy of fyer that will admit no ≈øaluation to any Papi≈øt.

3. Be≈øids this open confefsion of diuers Prote≈øtants for the truth of S. Au≈øtins Religion, it may be al≈øo conuinced out of diuers other things which them ≈øelues teach. For it being ≈øuppo≈øed out of Gods word heb. 11 that without the right faith it is impo≈øsible to plea≈øe God: and withall confe≈ø≈øed of diuers Prote≈øtants that S. Au≈øtin and his fellowes were holy men, it nece≈ø≈øarily followeth that his faith was the true faith of God.S. Au≈øtin and his follovvers holie men by Prote≈øt. Of S. Au≈øtins holines, & the Engli≈øh people in general ≈øome
thing hath bene ≈øayd before. Of others Fox lib. 2. pag. 123. ≈øaith Cutbert Iaruman, S. Cutbert Cedda and VVilfrid I iudge (≈øaith he) to be of a holy conuer≈øation. pag. 125.S. Aldelm. Aldelm a worthie and learned Bi≈øhop, of notable prai≈øe for his learning and vertue. Ibid. he calleth S. Iohn of Beuerly and S. Egwin Saints. pag. 127.S. Iohn Beuerly. Boniface. And yet pag. 129. calleth him a great ≈øetter vp and vphoulder of Popery. pag. 112. calleth king Edmond three tymes Saint. S. EdmoÃÑd. Item pag. 121. Cutbert Saint. Bale cent. 1. cap. 76. ≈øaith of S. Aidan, that he was a man of mo≈øt innocent life and ful of the ≈øpirit of God, and yet was O≈øwald his ≈øcholler a manife≈øt Papi≈øt, praying before cro≈ø≈øes and for the dead, euen when him ≈øelfe was redy to dye. ex Bed. lib. 3. cap. 2. & 12. The ≈øame Bale cent 1. cap. 83. ≈øaith, that Aldelm went happilie to Chri≈øt, and yet withal confe≈ø≈øeth
that he wrote for ≈øhauen crownes after the Roman maner, fea≈øts of Saints, ≈øingle lyfe, and ≈øuch things, and was long tyme familiar with P. Sergius. cent 1. cap. 93. He calleth Ceolfrid, Beda,S. Ceolfrid S. VVillebrord. Willebrord, Boniface and the like mo≈øt holy monkes, And addeth cent. 2. cap. 1. that Beda had a mo≈øt happie end; And yet the ≈øame man ≈øaith of Boniface pag. 79. that he brought the Germans to Papi≈øme: and pag. 103. VVas the next to the Pope the greate Antichri≈øt, and ≈øigned a hundred thou≈øand men in Bauaria with the Popes mark. And cent. 2. cap. 5. writeth that Willebrord preached Papi≈øtrie. Of S. Beda he ≈øaith cent. 2. cap. 1. That he can not be excu≈øed from all ≈øuper≈øtitious doctrine. And in the ≈øame place ≈øaith that Ceolfrid v≈øed the new ordinations of the Roman ≈øuper≈øtition. And that he was a plaine Papi≈øt appeareth by his epi≈øtle in Beda lib. 5. cap. 22. where he teacheth one ≈øacrifice of the bodie of Chri≈øt, rounde ≈øhauing of Monks, Calleth Peter head and Primat of the Apo≈øtles. Whervpon Fox lib. 2. pag. 126. termeth him a ≈øhaueling, condemneth him for calling Peter a Mediator, and termeth it a Monkish epi≈øtle, And in lyke ≈øort Bale ≈øpeaketh of diuers others.S. Hilda. For cent 1. cap. 94. he ≈øaith: S. Hilda Abbe≈ø≈øe was a mo≈øt holy woman, Ibid. Iohn of Beuerly a man very learned and pious, accounted it mo≈øt ≈øweet to preach Chri≈øts Go≈øpel out of the Pulpit, and ended his life in great con≈øtancie of
Euangelical ≈øpirit. And cent. 2. cap. 1. Calleth him a mo≈øt holy prelat. Cambden al≈øo De≈øcrip: Britan. pag. 518. Calleth S. Werburg Saint. S. VVerburg. S. Milburg. S. Botulph pag. 526. S. Milburg a mo≈øt holy virgin. p. 612. King O≈øwald Saint and pag. 150. That that age was mo≈øt fruitful of Saints. pag. 473. Botulph mo≈øt holy. And pag. 472. Guthlac lead his life in great holines. This by the confe≈ø≈øion of Prote≈øtants was the fruit of S. Au≈øtins religion. And if it be true, (as mo≈øt true it is which our Sauiour ≈øaid) that we can not gather grapes of thornes nor figges of brambles: And if it be true that vertue ≈øpringeth not out of the Diuels ≈øeede, nor Saints out of his Religion; Sure it is al≈øo, that S. Or haue they ≈øuch ≈økil as they can inuent new wayes to heauen be≈øides the way that Chri≈øt taught? And this for the vertue of S. Au≈øtins followers; Now let vs ≈øee what account Prote≈øtants make of the learning of ≈øome of them.

4. That we may be a≈ø≈øured that it was
not ignorance which made our Ance≈øtors imbrace S. Au≈øtins doctrine,That our Ance≈øtors follovved not S. Au≈øtin vpon ignorance S. Aldelm, Bale ≈øaith cent. 1. cap. 83. Did ≈øo ≈øtudie both Deuine, and Human learning, that be far pa≈ø≈øed all the Deuines of his tyme, mo≈øt learned in Greeke, and Latin, S. Aldelm. in Ver≈øe, and Pro≈øe, and cleare in wit and ≈øpeeche. Fox Acts 125. ≈øaith, he was a learned Bishop of worthy prai≈øe for his learning. Cambd. De≈øcript. Brit. 210. ≈øaith, he was ≈øurely worthie that his memorie ≈øhould remain for euer. For he was the fir≈øt Englishman that wrote in Latin, and fir≈øt that taught Englishmen to make Latin Ver≈øes. He became Very learned, in Poetrie excellent, and writ much in Greek and Latin, Pro≈øe and Ver≈øe, but his cheefe ≈øtudie was Deuinitie, in the which no man of his tyme was comparable vnto him. And yet the ≈øame Maidulph, (≈øaith Cambden Brit. pag. 210,) was of great learning and ≈øinguler pietie. S. Beda. Of S. Beda Bale cent. 2. cap. 1. giueth this te≈øtimonie. He was ≈øo practi≈øed in Prophane writers that he ≈øcarce
had his match in that age, he learnt Phi≈øick, and Metaphi≈øick out of the pure≈øt fountains. He knew the mi≈øteries of the Chri≈øtian faith ≈øo ≈øoundly, (note) that for his exact knowledg both of Greeke and Latin many preferred him before Gregorie the Great. There is ≈øcarce any thing worth reading to be found in all Antiquitie which in due places is not read in Beda „Äà‚óä„Äâ if he had liued in the tymes of Au≈øtin, Hierom, Chri≈øo≈øtom; I doubt not but he might haue contended for equalitie with them. He put forth many bookes ful of all kind of learning. Thus Bale of S. Beda: and in like ≈øort Fox Acts. pag. 127. ≈øaith, he was a man of worthy and memorable memory and famous learning, The whole Latin Church at that tyme gaue him the mai≈øtry in iudgement, and knowledg of the holy ≈øcripture. Stow Chron. pag. 93. Beda a famous learned man. Cooper Chron. An. 729. Beda for his learning and godly life was renowned in all the world. Bede the ≈øinguler glorie of England, by pietie and erudition obtained the name of venerable, wrote manie volumes, mo≈øt learnedly. And yet how plaine a Papi≈øt S. Beda was ≈øhalbe ≈øhewed both by his owne doctrine, and by open confe≈ø≈øion of Prote≈øtants cap. 17.

5. The third wherof I will ≈øpeake is Alcuin ≈øcholler to S. Beda,Alcuin. but mai≈øter to Charles the great. Of whome. Bale cent. 2
c. 17. VVriteth thus. He was thought by far the mo≈øt learned Diuine of his age, yea of all English men from the beginning after Aldelm and Beda, in ≈øo much that he was mai≈øter to Charles the great, and the fir≈øt beginner of the Vniuer≈øitie of Paris, ≈økilful in Latin, Greeke, and Hebrew. Our three Ma≈ø≈øes on chri≈øtma≈ø≈øe day, Our Candlels on Candlema≈ø≈øe day, Our Ceremonies in the holy weeke of keeping the Sepulcher, hallowing the font, putting out all the candels but one. Ther he ≈øhall ≈øee our ≈øeauen orders, our attire of Bi≈øhops at ma≈ø≈øe, our Tran≈øub≈øtantiation, our Extreme Vnction, and that acounted a SacrameÃÑt, our Confe≈øsion of all our ≈øinnes, our ≈øinging Ma≈ø≈øe, and praying for the dead. The≈øe, to omit innumerable more, confe≈ø≈øed in lyke maÃÑner by Prote≈øtaÃÑts to haue bene great ≈øchollers, and profound Diuines, ≈øhew that it was not ignorance or want of knowledg which made our Forfathers to follow S. Au≈øtins doctrin, nor that the Prote≈øtants learned men haue by their learning di≈øcouered
in it errors, as they call them. For whome haue they had comparable to any of the≈øe in learning, and indu≈øtry whome of their owne haue they ≈øo much commended as they haue done the≈øe?Comparai≈øon of Prote≈øt: learned men vvith ours Let any Prote≈øtant de≈øirous of truth take Tindal, Latimer, Ridley (whome they terme the Apo≈øtles of England) and con≈øider whither in learning, or vertue they be comparable to the≈øe three. And then iudge with indifferency on who≈øe ≈øide truth is mo≈øt lykely to ≈øtand. For all rea≈øon teacheth that they are mo≈øt lykely to find truth, who abounded with mo≈øt learning to ≈øearch it, and were indued with mo≈øt vertue to haue it from God. What rea≈øonable man then is ther that for≈øaking the Doctrine of S. Aldelm, S. Beda, and Alcuin, whome not onely wee, but very Prote≈øtants confe≈ø≈øe to haue bene mo≈øt indu≈øtrious to finde truth, mo≈øt ≈økilful to di≈øcerne it, and mo≈øt vertuous to de≈øerue to haue it taught of God, will follow Tindal, Latimer, Ridley, who≈øe learning by the iudgment of Catholiques was very meane, and their life very vicious; and by the iudgement of their own men are but meanly commended either for good life, or good learning.

div.head: CHAP. XIII. That the Doctrine which S. Au≈øtin preached he ≈øealed and confirmed by true miracles.
div.p:
Hovv manie kindes of proofes for S. Au≈øtins miracles.1. THat Saint Au≈øtin confirmed his doctrine by miracles, I will proue. Fir≈øt by the te≈øtimony of tho≈øe who liued in his tyme, ≈øecondly by the te≈øtimony of tho≈øe that liued ≈øoone after, and la≈øtly by the plain confe≈øsion of Prote≈øtants.VVitne≈ø≈øes then liuing. Of tho≈øe that liued in his tyme, fir≈øt is S. Gregory who writing to Eulogius Patriarch of Alexandria lib. 7. epi≈øt. 30. ≈øaith.S. Gregorie. Both he (Au≈øtin) and they, vvho vvere ≈øent vvith him ≈øhine vvith ≈øo great miracles in that (Engli≈øh) Nation, that they may ≈øeeme to imitat the vertues of the Apo≈øtles by the miracles, vvhich they vvorke. And lib. 9. epi≈øt. 56. writing to the Queene of France ≈øaith. VVhat and hovv great miracles our Redeemer hath vvrought in the conuer≈øion of the for≈øaid (Engli≈øh) Nation, The Q. of France knevv that our nation vvas conuerted by great miracles. yt is alredy knovvn vnto your Excellency. And can any man thinck that this great Doctor would write to a Queene of France that ≈øhe knew what miracles were done in England, if they
were not manife≈øt, and out of all doubt? And lib. 9. epi≈øt. 58. writing to S. Au≈øtin him ≈øelfe he ≈øaith. Reioice that English mens ≈øoules are by outvvard miracles dravvne to invvard grace. Ib. Diligently di≈øcu≈ø≈øe thy ≈øelf, vvho thou arte, and hovv great the grace is in that Nation, for who≈øe conuer≈øion thou ha≈øt receaued the gift of miracles. And lib. 27. Moral.. cap. 6. VVheras by good precepts, and heauenly words, yea with manife≈øt miracles too, the grace and knowledg of God is powred into it (Engli≈øh harts) &c. By which words (≈øaith S. Beda lib. 2. cap. 1.) this holy Father doth declare that Au≈øtin and his company brought the English men to the knowledg of truth, not onely by preaching to them in word but al≈øo by ≈øhewing them heauenly ≈øignes and miracles.

2. The ≈øecond te≈øtimonie is the publick Epitaph which the Engli≈øh men ≈øet vpon S. Au≈øtins Tombe after his death in the≈øe wordes.S. Au≈øtins Epitaph. Here resteth the body of S. Honorius. Which Pal was giuen by Popes to Metropolitans as a token of agreement in faith. And therfor Pope Pelagius Predece≈ø≈øor to S. Greg. decreed D. 100. After vve had read the letters of our deere ≈øonne King Edbald we vnder≈øtood vvith vvhat great learning and in≈øtruction of holy ≈øcripture yovv haue brought him to the beleefe of the vndoubted faith. Yea S. Au≈øtin in his ≈øpeech to King Ethelbert in Capgraue calleth S. Greg. totius Chri≈øtianitatis Patrem, the Father of all Chri≈øtendom. And thus much of S. Au≈øtin and his fellowes deedes, and doctrine out of Chatholick writers.S. Au≈øtins acts of Papi≈øtrie out of Prote≈øtants. Now let vs come to Prote≈øtants. 3. Bil≈øon and Abbots a ‚Ä¢ is afor≈øaid call S. Au≈øtin a Romish Monk, a Romish Prie≈øt, a Romish Legat. Which names ≈øhew of what Religion they account him.Abbots. Godwin in vit. Aug. ≈øaith, S. te≈øtifieth (as before we heard out of Saint Beda) that S. Au≈øtin came with a ≈øiluer Cro≈ø≈øe and Image of our Lord and Sauiour painted in a table, ≈øinging Litanies. div.p:
D. Abbots 1. DOctor Abbots in his late an≈øwer to Doct. Bi≈øhop pag. 197. calleth S. Au≈øtin a black Monk. pag. 20. The Italian Monk, brought new ob≈øeruations from Rome, and the English receaued the ≈øame. pag. 198. A Romish Prie≈øt, required the British Bishops to be ≈øubiect to his Romish authoritie. And that Chri≈øtian Religion vvhich he found in the Britons he labored to corrupt vvith Romish inuentions. 1. Cor. 15. Au≈øtin did not in all points teach the true faith to the Saxons. 2. Cor. 12. To vvit Altars, Ve≈øtements, Ma≈ø≈øes, Chalices, Cro≈ø≈øes, Candle≈øticks, Cen≈øars, Banners, holy Ve≈ø≈øels, holy vvater, and bookes of Roman cu≈øtoms.B. Bale. See Magdeburgen≈øes cent. 6. Bale cent. 1. pag. 19. After Au≈øtins Apo≈øtleship (≈øaith he) vnder the English Saxons there followed an other kind of Monkes which corrupted all with mo≈øt filthy ≈øuper≈øtitions & Idolatries. And cent. 1. cap. 70. Au≈øtin entred not with the Go≈øpel (of Luther) of Chri≈øtian peace, but with the banner of his Apo≈øtleship, with a ≈øiluer Cro≈ø≈øe, Letanies, Proce≈øsion, Images, painted Pictures, Reliques, and ritual bookes. And cap. 72. Au≈øt. made Elbald drinck of the cup of the whore, cap. 73. King Ethelbert fir≈øt of all English men receaued of Greg. 1. Bishop of Rome by Au≈øtin the opinions of the Roman ReligioÃÑ with all (≈øaith he) the impo≈øture or deceit, and dyed the one and twentith yeare of his receaued Papi≈øme. And pag. 73. he calleth our primitiue church a carnal Synagogue. And yet further cent. 8. cap. 85. Au≈øtin (≈øaith he) brought in Popish Monkerie, & be≈øides the Popes traditions (o filthie and bla≈øphemous mouth) brought no thing but mans dung. Cent. 13. c. 1. Au≈øtin the Roman brought hither Romish rites without ≈øound doctrine. The King receaued Romani≈øme with the anexed Idolatries. He brought in Monkes, Altars, Ve≈øtements, Images, Ma≈ø≈øes, Chalices, Cro≈ø≈øes,
Candle≈øticks Banners, holy (as they call them) Ve≈ø≈øels, holy water, and bookes of Roman cu≈øtoms. Their cheeffe≈øt ≈øtudies were about the oblations of Ma≈ø≈øes. And finally Cent. 14. cap 31. he ≈øaith, Au≈øtin di≈øpo≈øed all things in England to the forme of the Sinagogue of Rome, and made English men honorers of the Pope. Thus plainly is S. Au≈øtins Roman Religion confe≈ø≈øed by Bale who was both as earne≈øt a Prote≈øtant and as skilful in antiquities as euer ‚Ä¢ ngli≈øh Prote≈øtant was. Holin≈øhead. Holin≈øhead al≈øo De≈øcript. Brit. cap. 27. ≈øaith The Inhabitants of Britanie receaued the Doctrine of Rome brought in by Au≈øtin and his Monks. Ib. Au≈øtin indeed conuerted the Saxons from Pagani≈øme but imbued them with no le≈ø≈øe hurtful ≈øuper≈øtition than they did know before. For be≈øides the name ef Chri≈øt and external contempt of their pri≈øtinat Idolatrie, he taught them nothing at all, but rather made an exchange from gro≈ø≈øe to ≈øubtil trecherie, from open to ≈øecret Idolatrie, and from the name of Pagans to the bare Title of Chri≈øtians. So far were the≈øe men from thincking S. Au≈øtin to haue bene a Prote≈øtant, or to haue agreed with them as Fulk would 2. Cor. 12. in the cheefe and mo≈øt e≈ø≈øential points of faith.

div.head: CHAP. XVIII. That all the Archbishops of Canterburie from S. Au≈øtin to our tyme were Roman Catholicks, proued by generall rea≈øons.
div.p:
1. FIr≈øt, becau≈øe there is no mention or memorie in any Chronicle of England,No record that anie Archb: vvas Prote≈øt: befor this time. in any writer dome≈øtical or forrein, no record or monument of antiquitie that til Cranmer any of the Archbi≈øhops varied from the faith of his Predece≈ø≈øors. Secondly becau≈øe all the Archbi≈øhops vnto S. Odo his tyme (which was An. 958.) had bene Monks as S. Au≈øtin was, which Odo him≈øelfe te≈øtifieth in Malmesb. lib. 1. Pontif. pag. 200. And after that vnto Archbi≈øhop Baldwin an. 1184. in a manner all the Archbi≈øhops were Monks, as Godwin a Prote≈øtant yet liuing (which ≈øhall ≈øuffice to aduerti≈øe the Reader of now becau≈øe herafter I ≈øhall often allegd him) te≈øtifieth in the life of Archbi≈øhop Hubert. Thirdly,Archb: vvere cho≈øen by Monks. they were elected by the Monks of Chri≈øt-church in Canterburie where were Monks (≈øaith Malmsburie lib. 1. Pont. p. 203) euer ≈øince the tyme of S. Laurence ≈øucce≈ø≈øor to S. Au≈øtin as is euident by the epi≈øtle of Pope Boniface to King Ethelbert Ibid. pag. 208. and appeareth both by their liues in Godwin, and by the iudgment of Pope Innocent 3. in Paris pag. 287. Who, when the Bi≈øhops of England challenged right in the election of the Archbi≈øhop, the Pope hearing both parties gaue ≈øentence that Monachi legittim√® probauerunt &c. That the Monks had lawfully proued, that the ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ or and Couent of the Church of Canterbury haue for long times pa≈øt elected Bishops in their Chapter without the Bishops euen vnto this time, and haue obtained their election

And pag. 349. that it hath bene alwaies the practice of the Church of Rome euer to haue the Archbishops of their owne ≈øetting vp, or ≈øuch a one as they might be ≈øure of on their ≈øide. 458. ≈øaith that Pelagius le≈øt he ≈øhould rashly giue con≈øent to the allowing of any Metropolitan that were not ≈øound in faith, required them to make profe≈øsion of their faith and ≈øo to ≈øend for the Pal, that is to ≈øay to ≈øend for his con≈øent wherof the Pall was a token. div.p:
9. THe 40. div.head: Stephen Langton Archbishop XLIII.
div.p:

div.p:

div.p:
18. THe 49. Archbi≈øhop was Robert VVinchel≈øey, elected an. 1294. & decea≈øed an. 1313. Wal≈øingham ypodigmat. pag. 100. writeth of him that. He ruled

div.head: Thomas Cranmer Archbishop LXVIII.
div.p:
37. THe 68. Archb. but fir≈øt for≈øaker of S. Au≈øtin and his Predece≈ø≈øors faith was Thomas Cranmer in the year 1533. and put to death 1556. He was not cho≈øen for any de≈øerts, but being Chaplin to Anne Bullen, and known to de≈øire her preferment and to further King Henries lu≈øts, was by him fir≈øt ≈øent in Emba≈øsie about the diuorce, as yow may ≈øee in Fox pag. 1689. and after nominated to this dignitie,VVh ‚Ä¢ Cranmer vvas made Archb. to the end that if the Pope refu≈øed to pronounce ≈øentence of diuorce betweene him and Queene Catherin, Cranmer might do it. He was ≈øo carnal and ≈øo womani≈øh,His carnalitie. as his own mother would often ≈øay, ≈øhe euer thought women would be his vndoing. Wherin ≈øhe was nothing deceaued. For as Godwin confe≈ø≈øeth. He being yet very yong left his fellswship in Ie≈øus Colledg in Cambridg for loue of a woman
whome he maried. And after, being Archb. in his return from Rome, he brought with him a Duchwoman, to whome (≈øaith Fox pag. 1037.) it is ≈øuppo≈øed he was married, whome all King Henries time he carried vp and downe with him in a Trunck, and in King Edwards tyme married her. He was al≈øo trecherous to his Prince. For abbeit he had receaned ≈øo great fauors of King Henrie 8. and was by him,His treacherie to his Prince. apointed one of the Executors of his will, yet ≈øtreight after his death he agreed to the breaking of it. And after King Edwards death wrought all he could to the aduancing of Queene Iane & vtter excluding from the crowne of King Henries lawful daughter and his right Prince Queene Marie and fir≈øt ≈øub≈øcribed to the di≈øenheriting of Queene Marie,His rebellion. and to that rebellious letter which he and his accomplices ≈øent to Queene Marie,Fox. pag. 1698. And Fox to his euerla≈øting confu≈øion hath ≈øet downe in his Acts pag. 1299. edit. 1596. and maruel it were if one who thus for≈øooke God and his Prince, ≈øhould not al≈øo for≈øake his Predece≈ø≈øors faith?Cranmer for≈øoke God and his prince If he who had thus lo≈øt, as Saint Paul ≈øpeaketh, a good con≈øcience ≈øhould not al≈øo make ≈øhip wrack of his faith.Hovv long a Rom. Cathol. For fir≈øt he was a Roman Catholick, and ≈øo continewed from his childhood til he was
Archbi≈øhop, and a while after. At his fir≈øt going to the Pope was by him made his Penitentiarie as Fox hath edit: 1596. pag. 1690. went to Rome for his Pal and there tooke the v≈øual oath of fidelitie to the Pope. But in the next yeare after, to wit in the yeare 1534. When king Henrie by Parliament procured him ≈øelf to be tearmed head of the Church he al≈øo for≈øooke the Pope in that point yet in all other agreed with him as the king did, and both by words and deedes per≈øecuted the Prote≈øtants,Song Ma≈ø≈øe ≈øolemly in King Edvvard 6. time. as you may ≈øee in Fox in Lamberts death and others. And after King Henries death vnder king Edward ≈øonge Ma≈ø≈øe with great maie≈øtie for the king of France his ≈øoule a≈ø≈øi≈øted with 8. Bi≈øhops as writeth Stow Chron.Incon≈øtant euen in here≈øie. pag. 1547. yet after he fel to Lutherani≈øm, and ≈øet out a Cathechi≈øme wherin with Luther he taught the real pre≈øence of Chri≈øt in the ble≈ø≈øed Sacrament;Sliedan lib. 26. An. 1555. But ≈øtaying not long there, from thence turned with the Duke of Somer.In his recantation in fox pag. 1710. He taketh god to vvitnes he recanted of his ovvne minde and for con≈øcience ≈øake, and yet ≈øoone after recalled his retantation. Cranmet condemned for rebellion and herefir. Sleidan l. 25. f. 429. The mi≈øerable end of the Archb: that fir≈øt forfooke S. Au≈øtins faith. The great nobilitie rare learning and vertue of card. Pole. to Zuingliani≈øme, and publi≈øhed an other Cathechi≈øme which denyed the real pre≈øence. After all this vnder Queene Marie for hope of life recanted all his here≈øies, and both by tongue and penne profe≈ø≈øed the Roman Catholick faith. But perceauing that he ≈øhould die, choo≈øing rather to die in account of Prote≈øtants a
martyr, than in iudgment of both them and vs a malefactor, he finally ended his life in Zuingliani≈øme, being both condemned for Here≈øie again≈øt God, and for rebellion again≈øt his Prince as Fox confe≈ø≈øeth pag. 1698. Edit. 1596. And ≈øo as his faith had bene far different for a time from his Predede≈ø≈øors ≈øo was his end ignominious and far from the glorie of their happie departures.

div.head: Reginald Poole Archb. LXIX.
div.p:
30. THe 69. and la≈øt Catholich Archb. hithertho, was Reginald Poole con≈øecrated an. 1555. and departed this life an. 1558. the ≈øame yeare and day that Queen Marie died. He was ≈øonne to Syr Richard Pool Co≈øin german to King Henrie 8. and of Margaret Counte≈ø≈øe of Salsburie Daughter of George Duke of Clarence and brother of King Edward 4. He was a man (≈øaith Godwin) of manifold and excellent partes, not onely very learned, which is better known than it neede many wordes, but al≈øo of ≈øuch mode≈øtie in behauiour and integritie of life and conuer≈øation, as he was of all men both loued and reuerenced. And beyond ≈øeas he was ≈øo famous, that without all ≈øeeking of his he was fir≈øt made Cardinal, after
Legat to the Councel of Trent and twi≈øe elected Pope;Card. Poole might haue bene Pope. Ridley highly commended Card. Pool. His Rom. Religion. to which ≈øupreme dignitie wanted nothing but his owne con≈øent. He was by the confe≈øsion of Ridley in Fox Edit. 1596. pag. 1595. a man worthy of all humilitye reuerence and honor, and indued with manifould graces of learning and vertue. As for his Roman religion it might ≈øeeme needles to proue it if Doctor Bukley and ≈øome other Mini≈øters were not a≈øhamed to challeng him for a Prote≈øtant who≈øe impudencie I will refel with the te≈øtimonie of their owne Authors. For Godwin ≈øaith in King Henries time he dealt by letters to his frends to exhort them from all conformitie to reformation and being accu≈øed in the Conclaue of fauering prote≈øtants and of other matters, He cleared him≈øelf (≈øaith Godwin) of all the≈øe ≈øu≈øpitions ab≈øolutely ≈øo that the next day they were more re≈øolute to make him Pope than before. And infra he ≈øaith Queene Marie loued him for his learning and nobilitie but aboue all for his religion and finally that he reconciled England to the Pope and receiued from him his Pal. Bale Cent 8. cap. 100. ≈øaith he was a Cardinal ≈øoldier of Antichri≈øt, not to be commended for any vertue by the ≈øeruant of God, and ≈øaith that in an Oration to the Emperor he called the German Prote≈øtants newe Turks, Sleidan lib. 10. in fin. and their Go≈øpel Turcicum
pe≈øtiferum & adulterinum ≈øemen Turkish pe≈øtiferous and adulterous ≈øeede. An. 1607. which Cra≈øhew was not a ≈øhamed in his ≈øermon at Paules Cro≈ø≈øe to affirme that Poole ≈øaid o the written word of God. Farther more Bale termeth this worthie Prelat and great ornament of our Nation horrible bea≈øt a rooter out of the truth of the Go≈øpel a mo≈øt wicked Traitor to his Contrie, and prayeth God to confound him. So vndoubted it was while Cardinal Poole liued that he was no Prote≈øtant but a mo≈øt earne≈øt Roman Catholick.See Andreas Dioditius in vit. Poli. Which who readeth his booke and con≈øidereth his deedes may yet ≈øee more fully. But by him may the iudicious reader ≈øee with what truth or face our Mini≈øters challeng S. Au≈øtin and other holy and antient Archbi≈øhops of Canterburie to be of their religion.

div.head: Epilog.Fir≈øt and la≈øt Cath. Archb of Canterb. ≈øaid Ma≈ø≈øe and haue palls from Rome. The number of our Archb. Their continuance, learning vertue and vvi≈ødom.
div.p:
39. THus yow ≈øee the fir≈øt and the la≈øt of the Catholick Archbi≈øhops of Canterburie, namely S. Au≈øtin and Cardinal Pole to haue ≈øaid Ma≈ø≈øe and had their Palls from Rome, and all of them (except one) euer ≈øince the fir≈øt Chri≈øtianitie of our Nation vnto our daies, for number thre ≈øcore and nine for continewance of nine hundred fi≈øty and eight
yeares, for learning many of them mo≈øt famous, for wi≈ødom mo≈øt excellent, and for vertue diuers of them mo≈øt admirable, as you haue heard by the very confe≈øsion of Prote≈øtants them ≈øelues.VVho vvil not advventure his ≈øoule rather vvith the≈øe than vvith Cranmer. Thus manie (I ≈øay) thus excellently qualified Primats and Pa≈øtors of al England, thus long to haue taught the Catholick faith, to haue followed it them ≈øelues, to haue defended it with their great learning, maintained it by their miracles, authorized it by their notable vertues, and finally to haue liued in it mo≈øt religiou≈øly, and died mo≈øt happely; What ≈øhall wee thinck of them? That ≈øo many, and great Clerks were ≈øo many hundred yeares ignorant of the truth? That ≈øo many and ≈øo great Saints ≈øo long tyme mi≈ø≈øed of the way to heauen? That all our Ance≈øtors who ≈øo many yeares followed them were chri≈øtened in vaine, beleeued in vaine, and wor≈øhiped and ≈øerued God in vaine, and finally died in their ≈øinnes; and are damned and gon to hel?No vvaie to heauen but by Chri≈øt and his true faith. As we mu≈øt needs thinck vnles we graunt the Roman Catholick faith to be the faith of Chri≈øt and right way to ≈øaluation. Shall, I ≈øay ≈øuch an vnchri≈øtian, vnnatural, and vnrea≈øonable thought enter into our harts? And not rather follow the adui≈øe of S. Paul ≈øaying Mementote Praepo≈øitorum ve≈øtrorum qui vobis locuti ≈øunt
verbum Dei, quorum intuentes exitum conuer≈øationis imitamini fidem, Beholding the end of the coÃÑuer≈øation of your Prelats follovv their faith. Let vs behould the holy conuer≈øation and happie & vertuous ende of tho≈øe holy and worthy Prelat: and primats of England, a≈ø≈øuring our ≈øelues that vertue can not follow the Diuel, nor Gods Saints be condemned to Hel. Let vs embrace their faith which was the roote of their vertue, and their cheefe guide in their way to heauen, whither they are happily ariued and we ≈øhall a≈ø≈øuredly follow if we keepe their faith and imitat their vertue. And thus hauing ≈øhewed that all our Archbi≈øhops of Canterburie, and con≈øequently all our Clergie, Bi≈øhops, Archdeacons, Deacons Canons, Pa≈øtors, Vicars, Monkes,All Be≈øides VViclef and his ≈ømall number. and Friers were Roman Catholicks euen from the fir≈øt Chri≈øtianity of our Nation to our age, Let vs proc ‚Ä¢ ed an ≈øhew the ≈øame of our Chri≈øtian Kings and Laitie.

div.head: CHAP. XXI. That all our Chri≈øtian English kings to king Henrie 8. time were Roman Catholicks proued by general rea≈øons.
div.p:
1 No record that anie of our old chri≈øtian Kings vvas Prote≈øtant.1. FIr≈øt becau≈øe (as I ≈øaid of the Archbi≈øhops) ther is no ≈øcript, no ≈øcrole, no record, no monument, to te≈øtifie that our former Chri≈øtian kings were of any other religion than king Henrie 8. was before he began the change. Therfor they that affirme the contrarie either know it by reuelation, or ≈øpeake without booke. Be≈øides it is impo≈ø≈øible that ther ≈øhould be an alteration in religion which is the mo≈øt markable≈øt thing in a Common welth, and that there ≈øhould be no mention therof; and altogether incredible in England, where we ≈øee the fir≈øt alteration from Pagani≈øme to Chri≈øtianitie, and now lately from Papi≈øtrie to Prote≈øtancie recorded in all Hi≈øtories. yea priuat mutations made by kings in ≈øome Churches from Prie≈øts to monks or contrary wi≈øe. And can we thinck that a mutation from Prote≈øtancie to Papi≈øtrie
(if any ≈øuch had bene) would haue bene omitted and forgotten. 2. All the Archbi≈øhops of Canterburie were Roman Catholicks as is before ≈øhewed,2 All their Archb. vvere Catholicks. and yet none of them trobled by the kings of former times for his religion‚ñ™ yea mo≈øt of them greatly honored by them, and diuers made Archbi≈øhops by their kings procurment.3 They ≈øuffered Archb. to be con≈øecrat of the Pope. &c. 3. They ≈øuffered the ≈øaid Archbi≈øhops to go to Rome (where diuers of them were con≈øecrated of the Pope) to receaue their Pal, to be his legat, and take their for≈øaid oath of fidelitie to the Pope, which if they had bene Prote≈øt. and not perfect Roman Catholick they would neuer haue permitted. yea ≈øome of the kings procured Pals for their Archb:Kings procure palls from the P. for their Archb. as King Edwin for S. Paulin in Beda lib. 2. cap. 17,. King Alfwald for Archbi≈øhop Eanbald, Florent. An. 779. Huntington lib.. 3. king Rufus for S. An≈øelm, Fox Acts. pag. 185. 4. Nine of the ancient kings left their Kingdomes and became monks,4 Manie ancient Kings became Monks. as Fox confe≈ø≈øeth Acts. pag. 133. who≈øe names are the≈øe, king Kinegilfus, K. Cedwalla, king Ina, king Ethelred, king Sigebert, king Coenred, king Offa, king Edbert,Monks vovved cha≈øtie pouertie and obedience. to whome pag. 131. he addeth king Kenred. Now moÃÑkes in that time vowed cha≈øtitie as is euident in S. Beda lib. 5. cap. 22. lib. 4. cap. 25. lib. 3. cap. 25. And
Pouertie lib. 1. cap. 25. And obedience. lib. 4. cap. 5. And how Papi≈øtical this is, and contrary to Prote≈øtancie euery one knoweth. Be≈øide as Fox ≈øaith pag. 115. mo≈øt like they did this for holines ≈øake, thincking in this kind of life to ≈øerue or plea≈øe God better, or to merit more which Kinde of act or ende of theirs is plain Papi≈øtical, and quite oppo≈øit to Prote≈øtancie. And therfore Fox ≈øaith, that the≈øe Kings were far deceaued. To the≈øe Kings we may adioin 19. Queenes and Kings daughters whome Fox al≈øo pag. 134. confe≈ø≈øeth to haue left their royall e≈øtate,Manie ancient Queenes and K. Daughters nunnes. and becommen Nunnes. Princes, Dukes, Earles, Barons, and Rulers of Churches incen≈øed with a de≈øire of heauen, laboring and ≈øtriuing among them ≈øelues to enter into Monkerie into voluntarie exile and ≈øolitarie life, for≈øooke all and followed the Lord. The ≈øame hath Huntington. lib. 5. Houed. and others. Is this thinck we a proceding of Prote≈øtants or rather of earne≈øt and deuout Roman Catholicks?

5 Out ancient Kings de≈øire the P. to confirme their Charters.2. Fiftly. They de≈øired the Pope to confirme their Charters which they made. This you may ≈øee of King Ethelbert the fir≈øt Chri≈øtian King, in Malmsb: lib. 1. Pont. pag. 208. Of King Coenred and King Offa in Capgraue in vita Egwin.
Of King Egbert in Florent. Chron. An. 676. of King wulfer in Ingulf. pag: 884. Of an other King Offa in Paris An. 794. Of King Edgar in Malmsb. lib. 2. Reg. pag. 57. 6. They ≈øuffered appeals to Rome from them ≈øelues.6 Kings ≈øuffer appeals to Rome. This is euident in King Egbert and King Alfred in Beda lib. 5. cap. 20. 7. They beleeued S. Peter to be Prince of the Apo≈øtles as is to be ≈øeene in King Offa his Charter in Cambden in Brit.7 Our Kings beleeue S. Peters ≈øupremacie. pag. 613. and S. Peter to be higher in degree than S. Paule, as is to be ≈øeene in King Ina his ver≈øes there pag. 193. and Peter onely to haue had the keies. to witt of all the Church, as Reinolds confe≈ø≈øeth Confer. pag. 12, And finally the Church of Rome in their time to be the Catholick and Apo≈øtolick Church, as Beda te≈øtifieth lib. 3. cap. 29, at what time the Prote≈øtants account the Roman Church the who are of Babilon, and the Pope Antichri≈øt.8 Manie of our Kings canonized by the Pope. 8. Seuen of the≈øe our Engli≈øh Kings are Canonized by the Roman Church in the Martirologe, to wit, Ethelbert, Richard, O≈øwald, Sebbi, Edmund, Edward martir, Edward Confe≈ø≈øor, 9 Our ancient Kings knovv not iu≈øtification by onely faith. which would neuer haue bene done if they had not bene Roman Catholicks.

9. Our ancient Engli≈øh Kings could be no Prote≈øtants therfore they were Roman Catholicks. For no others challenge
them for theirs. That they could be no Prote≈øtants is mo≈øt manife≈øt. Fir≈øt becau≈øe the opinion of iu≈øtification by onely faith is accounted of Prote≈øtants the foundation, VVhat is the foundation and ≈øoul of Protete≈øtancie Luther. head, and cheefe≈øt point and ≈øoule of their Doctrin and Church, It is (≈øaith Luther Prefat. in Ionam) the head of Chri≈øtian Religion, the ≈øumme of the ≈øcriptures. Prefat: ad Galath: If the article of Iu≈øtification (by onely faith) be once lo≈øt, then is all true Chri≈øtian doctrin lo≈øt. And as many as hould not that doctrin are Iewes Turks Papi≈øts or hereticks. Item. By this onely doctrin the Church is built and in this it con≈øi≈øteth. And in cap. 1. Galath. If we neglect the Article of Iu≈øtification we lee≈øe all together. And in cap. 2. It is the principal Article of all Chri≈øtian doctrin all other Arcicles are comprehended in it. Fox Acts.Fox. pag. 840. ≈øaith It is the foundation of all Chri≈øtianitie, Chark. And pag. 770. the onely principal origen of our ≈øaluatian. Chark in the Tower di≈øputation ≈øaith. It is the ≈øoule of the Church. And the ≈øame ≈øay all other Protete≈øtants. But this foundation, this head, this ≈øoule of Prote≈øtancie, our ancient Kings knew not, as Fox plainly confe≈ø≈øeth in the≈øe wordes pag. 170. The Doctrin of Iu≈øtification (by onely faith) was then vnknown. And pag. 133. writeth thus of our antiente≈øt Chri≈øtian Kings.Our Kings knevv not the Prote≈øtant Go≈øpel. They lackt the doctrin and knowledg in Chri≈øts Go≈øpel e≈øpetially (≈øaith he) in the Article of free Iu≈øtification by faith
and therfor (≈øaith he) they ran the wrong way. Loe he granteth that they were ignorant e≈øpetially of that which Prote≈øt: e≈øteeme the e≈øpecialle≈øt point of Prote≈øtancie. And Ibid. ≈øpeaking of our ancient Chri≈øtian Kings hath the≈øe wordes: How great the blindnes and ignorance of the≈øe men was who wanting no zeale wanted knowledg, ≈øeeking their ≈øaluation by their meritorious deedes, which I write (≈øaith he) here to put vs in mind how much we at this pre≈øent are bound to God for the true ≈øinceritie of his truth hidden ≈øo long before to our fforance≈øtors, and opened now to vs. A plaine confe≈ø≈øion that none of our Anceitors vvere Prote≈øtants. This onely lamenting to ≈øee them haue ≈øuch works and want our faith, and vs to haue right faith and want their workes. div.p:
13. THe 24. K. was Edgar, ≈øecoÃÑd ≈øonne to king Edmund, who began his reigne, (≈øaith Malmsb. lib. 2. cap. 8.) Anno 959. and reigned 16. yeares.The prai≈øes of K. Edgar. Kings to row him in a boate, he ≈øetting at the ≈øterne & guiding it. The RomaÃÑ religioÃÑ of this renowned K. is manife≈øt. Peters in the Bi≈øhops hands. and ≈øaith to the Bi≈øhops, I haue Con≈øtantins ≈øworde, and yee haue Peters ≈øword in your hands, let vs ioine right hands, let vs cuple ≈øvvord to ≈øvvord that the Leapers may be ca≈øt out of the Temple. 15. IN the yeare 979. ≈øaith Malmsb. lib. 2. cap. 10. ≈øucceeded King Egelred, ≈øonne to King Edgar, and reigned 37. yeares. Who (as ≈øay Florent An. 978.Qualities of K. Egelred. div.p:
17. div.head: King S. Edward Confe≈ø≈øor. XXXI.
div.p:
Vertues of K. Edvvard CoÃÑfe≈øsor.20. IN the yeare 1042. Edward Confe≈ø≈øor & ≈øonne to the for≈øaid king Egelred began his reign, and reigned 24. yeares. Bal. ≈øupra. And pag. 16. calleth him vertuous and ble≈ø≈ø ‚Ä¢ d King. Now let vs ≈øee what the religion of this great and holy king was. Fir≈øt he vowed to God, that if he got the crowne he would go, to Rome on Pilgrimage, We≈øtmon. An. 1049. Ealred in vita Edwardi.
Secondly, when his people would not ≈øuffer him to leaue the Land for fear of the Danes inua≈øion, he demanded di≈øpen≈øation, and obtained it of Pope Nicholas. 2. Nichol. in ep. ad Edwardum. Ealred in vita: Thirdly, ≈øent two Abbots to a Concell held at Rhemes by Pope Leo, Florent. and Houed. Anno. 1050. Fourthly he built the Mona≈øtery of We≈øtmin≈øter: principally for the loue (≈øaith Camb. in Brit. pag. 376. of the cheefe Apo≈øtle, whome he honored with a ≈øpeciall & peculier affection. Fiftly, whiles he was at Ma≈ø≈øe, God reuealed vnto him the drowning of the K. of Denmarke which intended to inuade England. Houed. An. 1066. Ealred in vit. Sixtly, Pope Nicol. writing to him, thanketh God that King Edward had loue to S. Peter and with vs he con≈øented in all the Apo≈øtolicall Decrees, and therin ab≈øolued him from his vow, & We≈øtmin≈øter from all Epi≈øcopall iuri≈ødiction, and ≈øaith that to him and his ≈øucce≈ø≈øors we commit the aduou≈øion, and tuition of all the Churches of England that in any place yow may determine by the Coun≈øell of the Bishops and Abbots what things be iu≈øt and right. Whervpon Bale l. cit. ≈øaith: That ≈øub Nicolao 2. facti ≈øunt Anglorum Reges &c. vnder Pope Nicolas 2. the Kings of EnglaÃÑd were made the Popes Vicars. SeueÃÑtly, writing to the Pope. He profe≈ø≈øeth
the Popes ≈øupremacie, In which (as Prote≈øtaÃÑts ≈øay) the e≈ø≈øence of a Papi≈øt coÃÑ≈øi≈øteth, in the≈øe plain words, To the cheefe Father of the vniuer≈øall Church Nicolas, Edward by the grace of God K. of England due obedieÃÑce. And ≈øo manife≈øt it is, that this K. & our Country in his time were Roman Catholicks, as Syr Edward Cook the Kings Attorney in F. Henrie 4, and ‚Ä¢ . the verie midnight of Poperie, That times of England mo≈øt florishing vvhich Prote≈øt: confe≈ø≈øe to haue bene Papi≈øtical. which were in truth the mo≈øt florishing times, that euer England ≈øaw. For what King haue we in vertue comparable to King Edward Confe≈ø≈øor? in wi≈ødome, to King Henrie the fir≈øt? in valour and victories to King Edward the fir≈øt, the Conqueror of Scotland? and Henrie 4. of England, and Henrie the fift Conqueror of France?

div.head: King Herold. XXXII.
div.p:
21. THe 32. and la≈øt King of the Saxons was King Herold who tooke the crown An. 1066. and held it not one yeare.Valour of K. Herold. He was ≈øaith Cooper An. 1066. valiant and hardie. Florent. An. 1066. ≈øaith he was left ≈øucce≈ø≈øor by Saint Edward and cho≈øen of all the nobles of England and crowned of Aldred Archb. of yorke & began to put down vniu≈øt lawes & to ≈øet vp iu≈øt to become a Patron of Mona≈øteries, to honor and reuerence Bi≈øhops Abbots Monks and Clerkes, to ≈øhew him ≈øelfe pious humble and affable, to hate malefactors and to labour by ≈øea and Land for defence of his Countrie he ouerthrew the king of Norway in a great battel, but was ≈øone after him≈øelfe ≈ølayne and England coÃÑquered in a ruefull battel in Su≈ø≈øex by William Duke of Normandy and after king of England.His Rom. Religion. His Roman religion is manife≈øt both by what hath bene ≈øaid of king Edward, and becau≈øe as Cambd. hath in Brit pag. 384. VValtham Mona≈øterie he founded in the honor of the holie Cro≈ø≈øe where he made his vowes for victorie again≈øt the Normans. We≈øtmon An. 1066. ≈øaith, orauit ante crucem He prayed before the Cro≈ø≈øe. Thus yow ≈øee
the Roman Catholicke religion deduced not only fom all our Chri≈øtian kings for the 200. yeares vnto the Monarchie but al≈øo from the monarchie all the Saxons time vnto the conque≈øt therof by the Normans for the ≈øpace of 266. yeares: in which time two of the ≈øaid Kings haue bene Saints to wit Saint Edward martyr and Saint Edward Confe≈ø≈øor. Three haue gon on Pilgrimage to Rome, namely king Ethelwolph king Alfred the great and king Canut: To whome we may ad king Burdred and king Edward Confe≈ø≈øor who would haue gon. Two kings daughters Saints namely S. Edburga daughter to king Edward and S. Editha daughter to king Edgar. And if we will know why God permitted our Contry to be ≈øubdued of ≈øtrangers. It was ≈øaith Malmsb. lib. 3. in Guilielmo. 1. becau≈øe the ≈øtudies of learning and religion had decayed, Not a fewe yeares before the Normans coming the Clergie could ≈øcarce ≈øtamer out the words of the Sacraments, he which knew his graÃÑmer was a wonder and a miracle to the re≈øt, Monks vvere fine in apparell and had euery kinde of meat indifferent making a mockerie of their rule, The nobles giuin to glutonie and Venerie did not go to Church in the morning after the maner of Chri≈øtians but in their chambers dalying vvith their wiues heard onlie the ≈øolemnization of
their wiues heard onely the ≈øolemnization of Mattins and Ma≈ø≈øe by a Prie≈øt, making much ha≈øt therin. Euery one commonly was giuen to tippling continewing in this exerci≈øe nights as wel as dayes, wheron vices en≈øued companions of dronkenes. But I would not haue the≈øe ≈øayinges to be vnder≈øtood of all. I knew many of the clergie at that time walked the path of ≈øanctitie in true ≈øimplicitie. I knew many Laymen of all ≈øorts and conditions within this ≈øame Contrie plea≈øed God. Hunting. al≈øo lib. 6. writeth that before the Conque≈øt, a man of God tould them that for their ≈øinnes in murder and trea≈øon, and becau≈øe they were giuen to drunkenes and carele≈ønes of the ≈øeruice of God, ther ≈øhould come from France a Lord that ≈øhould depre≈ø≈øe them for euer, and not onely they but the Scotts al≈øo ≈øhould rule ouer them to their de≈øerued confu≈øion. div.head: CHAP. XXV. That the Kings of England from the Conque≈øt to King Edward 3. time, were Roman Catholicks proued in particuler.
div.p:
1. THe 33. King of England was William the Conqueror who entred this Land An. 1066. and reigned 21. yeares. He got the crowne of this Realm partly by dint of ≈øword and conque≈øt, partly by the graunt of King Edward Confe≈ø≈øor, who≈øe co≈øin German remoued he was. For as him ≈øelfe ≈øaith in his Charter, in Cambd. in Brit. pag. 111.VVhat right K. VVill. had to the Crovvne of England. He got the Kingdome by the help of the graunt of God and of his co≈øin glorious King Edward, who apointed him his adopted heir to the Kingdom of England. And Guitmundus in oratione ad Regem, ≈øaith: He got England by the gift of God and by the freindship of Edward his Kin≈øman. And Ingulph who then al≈øo liued, ≈øaith. An. 1065.
Edward cho≈øe VVilliam and ≈øent Robert Archb. of Canterb. who should declare it vnto him. And pag. 911. In the Kindred and con≈øanguinitie of Edward our famous King, VVilliam framed his con≈øcience to inuade England. Paris pag. 1057. It is ≈øayd that ble≈ø≈øed S. Edward gaue the Kingdom to VVilliam as a Legacie on his death bed. The like hath Wal≈øing. ypodigm pag. 28. Houed. pag. 609. and others. Finally Fox Acts pag. 165. And King William tru≈øting to the right of this title offered Herold (as Fox pag. 166. 167. and others write) to trye their two titles before the Pope, but Herold refu≈øing, William neuerthele≈ø≈øe ≈øent and got his title approued by the Popes iudgment. This King ≈øaith Hunting. lib. 6. pag. 370. was wi≈øe, Valour and vertues of K. VVilliam Conq. but crafty, rich but couetous, vain-glorious but louing his reputation, louing to the ≈øeruants of God, hard to this with≈øtanders, the onely author of peace that a little girle loaden vvith gould might pa≈ø≈øe tbrough EnglaÃÑd vntouched. The like hath Malmsb. lib. 3. and Cooper An. 1067; Bale Cent. 2. cap. 56. addeth
that he was of great corage and excellent in the knowledg of warlick affaires.His Rom. religion. His Roman religion is manife≈øt. Fir≈øt becau≈øe as We≈øtmon. An. 1085. and others write,Paris. An. 185. Euery day he vvas pre≈øent at Ma≈ø≈øe heard mattins Lauds Euen≈øong vvith the Canonicall houres, K. VVill. Conq. heard euery daie Ma≈ø≈øe mattins and Houre ‚Ä¢ . nether vvould he ≈øuffer euen vpon mo≈øt vrgent and difficult affaires, him ≈øelf to be hindred. In the meane ≈øea≈øon he cea≈ø≈øed not to kneele and to pray deuoutly. Secondly becau≈øe as ≈øone as he had gotten the victorie he ≈øent Herolds Standerd to the Pope. Stow in Herold, Cambd. in Brit. Thirdly he built two Mona≈øteries one at Battel in Su≈ø≈øex Vt orarent: that they might pray ≈øaith We≈øtmon. An. 1067. Paris 1066. Pro ibi mortuis for the dead there. And an other at Cane in Normandie. Fourthly he made his daughter Cecilia a Nonne:K. VVill. daughter a Nonne. Paris An. 1075. Stow. pag. 177. S. O≈ømund was ≈øo inward with this King as Bale ≈øaith Cent. 13. cap. 14. That he could not be ab≈øent ≈øcarce any time from King VVilliams pre≈øence. And yet as he both there ≈øaith, and Fox Acts pag. 184. Godwin in the Bi≈øhop of Salsburie, this O≈ømund in the yeare 1076. was author of the office or maner of ≈øaying Ma≈ø≈øe mattins and admini≈øtring Sacraments after the v≈øe of Sarum which (≈øaye they) was afterward in a manner receaued through all England Wales and Ireland.
Sixtlie Pope Alexander writing to him ep. 10. ≈øaith Among the Princes and rulers of the world we vnder≈øtand the notable forme of your religion, and writeth to him to per≈øi≈øt in the ≈øtudy of mo≈øt Chri≈øtian deuotion. And Pope Greg. 7. whome Prote≈øt. call Hilddebrand,Loue betvvene P. Hildebrand and K. VVilliliam. and hate mo≈øt of all the Popes lib. 1. ep. 31. calleth King William, the mo≈øt louing and principall ≈øonne of the Roman Church. And ep. 69. ≈øaith: That King William reioi≈øed in his promotion, and ≈øhewed all the affection of a good ≈øonne from his hart. And l. 6. ep. 30. Ninthlie, he glorieth in his death bed (as Stow Chron. pag, 171. Baron An. 1084. and an other author then pre≈øent write) that he had increa≈øed 9. Abbeies of Monks,VVhat account K. VVilliams la≈øt vvords praying to our ladies with great deuotion he lift vp his eyes to Heauen, and holding abroad his hands ≈øaid, I commend my ≈øoule vnto our ble≈ø≈øed Ladie Marie Mother of God, that she ‚Ä¢ y her holie praiers may reconcile me to her mo≈øt dere ≈øonne our Lord Ie≈øus Chri≈øt. div.head: King VVillam Rufus XXXIIII.
div.p:
3. THe 34. Chri≈øtian King of England was William Rufus Anno 1088. and reigned 13. yeares.Vertues of K. Rufus for a time. He (≈øaith Stow Chron. pag. 179.) as long as Lanfranc liued ≈øeemed to abhorre all kinde of vice, ≈øo that he was accounted a mirror of Kings. Cooper Anno 1089. writeth that in martiall policie he was verie expert, and diligent in all matters he went about, ≈øtedfa≈øt and ≈øtable in his promi≈øse, and meruailous painfull and laborious. But at la≈øt vices ouerwhelmed his vertues. His Rom. Religion His Roman religion is manife≈øt. Fir≈øt becau≈øe as Malmsb. hath lib. 4. Paris An. 1087. He was brought vp by Lanfranc, and by his meanes chiefly, made King. Secondlie becau≈øe Fox writeth lib. 4. pag. 184. Lincoln Min≈øter in his time had a Romish dedication. And as Paris ≈øaith pag. 767. that being done the king called two Cardinalls who were pre≈øent, who had receaued fulnes of power of our Lord the Pope for the di≈øpo≈øition of Bishopricks, and of the ≈øame Church. The ordination was ≈øuch, that the

The manner of Luthers proceding in Prote≈øtaÃÑti≈øme. His incon≈øtancie.6. Likewi≈øe An. 1519. which was the third yeare of his Prote≈øtaÃÑcy he wrote as Sleidan confe≈ø≈øeth, that in humane things nothing is more excellent than the Church of Rome be≈øide Chri≈øt only. This meane v≈øed al≈øo Caluin as witne≈ø≈øeth the for≈øaid Surueier c. 4.Surueyer. wher al≈øo he noteth that it is a plau≈øible matter with the people to hear then depraued that are in authoritie. his preaching expo≈øed to the praye of Princes and people. This bate v≈øed the wiclefi≈øts in K. Henrie 4. time to cach that worthie Prince as Stow reporteth, & with it partely, Prote≈øtants caught K. Henrie 8. and v≈øed it to others. For as the ≈øaid Surueier writeth. cap. 21. VVhen reformation of religion vvas fir≈øt vrged it vvas thaught ≈øuch an effectuall motiue as vvould procure attention vz to entitle Princes after a ≈øorte to the Church goods. 4 Prote≈øtation of fal≈øe preachers.4. On Luther and his partners ≈øide the fir≈øt meane of ≈øpreding their religion was which him ≈øelf in the≈øe words 4. Galat. fol. 211. noteth in fal≈øe Apo≈øtles. Galat. fol. 66.) is free from all lawes and ≈øubiect to no creature. And lib. de Captiu. A Chri≈øtian is bound to no law but to Gods. In like ≈øorte Luther remoued from his followers all difficult and hard things. 6. And on the other ≈øide, touching plea≈øures & delites of this world, he licen≈øed Bi≈øhops, Prie≈øts, Monks, Friers,Giueth licence to enioy all plea≈øures. & Nonnes to break their vowes of cha≈øtitie, pouerty, and obedience, and to marie, to

7. Fir≈øt (≈øaith he cap. 8. Luther and his parteners ≈øaught to per≈øuade the Pope and Bishops to to their reformation. Luthers means of ≈øpreading his doctrin out of the Surueyer. Thus yow ≈øee it euident eueÃÑ by the confe≈øsion of Prote≈øtants both the yeare when K. Henry 8, began to reuolt froÃÑ the Pope. To wit 1530. & his Coun≈øellers therin, to wit, no Bi≈øhops nor Diuines but Laymen; who hoped (as they were) to be partakers of the pray. And his motiue ther vnto, not di≈ølike of the P. religioÃÑ or like of a better, but malice again≈øt his persoÃÑ, & couetu≈ønes of the Church goods. And out of the≈øe two fouÃÑtains haue ≈øproÃÑg ≈øince all the Prote≈øtaÃÑcie of Engl. which whether they were liker to be fouÃÑtains of Gods or the Diuels religioÃÑ I leaue to euery one to iudg.

2.Prote≈øtancie quite altereth K. Henries procedings. And as the motiues ≈øo his alteratioÃÑ were malice & couetuo≈ønes, ≈øo his proceding after was euer cruell couetous & blooddy, quite differeÃÑt froÃÑ his procedings in the former time, For wheras before in 22. years of his Regn he had bene geÃÑtle & put none of his nobility to death be≈øides the Duke of Buckingham & Fearle of Suffolk for trea≈øon In 16. yeares after, of ≈øix Queenes which he had, he put away two, wherof one died for ≈øorow, other two he beheaded the one for adultery, the other for ince≈øt al≈øo, a thing vnheard of befor in Enlgi≈øh Q. the fift he cau≈øed to be opened for to ≈øaue

Lords. CouÃÑte≈ø≈øe. Marque≈ø≈øe. Rauin. and the ≈øixt he ment to haue executed for here≈øie. Of Cardidals he beheaded one, coÃÑdemned an other, brought the third to death with greefe and ≈øorow. Iames nere to Charing Cro≈ø≈øe Anno 1532. ≈øuppre≈ø≈øed the priory of the Trinity in London. Anno 1534. ≈øuppre≈ø≈øed the hou≈øes of the Ob≈øeruant Friers in EnglaÃÑd and tooke to him≈øelfe all fruits and tenths of all ≈øpirituall goods and promotions An. 1534. tooke the reliques and cheefe≈øt Iuells out of Mona≈øteries, Anno 1536. ≈øuppre≈ø≈øed all religious hou≈øes to the value of 200. poundes and vnder, and tooke all their lands and grounds. The number of
the≈øe hou≈øes (≈øaith Stow) were 276. the value of their lands then 32000. pounds and more by the year. The moueable goods as they vvere ≈øould at Robinhood penorthes amonted to more thaÃÑ one huÃÑdred thou≈øand pounds. It was a pitifull thing (≈øaith he) to heare vvhat a lamentation the poore people in the Countrey made for them. For there was great ho≈øpitality kept among them, and as it was thought more than 10. thou≈øand per≈øons Mai≈øters and ≈øeruants had lo≈øt their liuings by the putting downe of tho≈øe hou≈øes. Anno. 1538. All Abbeis and religious hou≈øes were ≈øuppre≈ø≈øed, and S. Thomas of Canterbury Shrine pulled downe, which was (≈øaith Stow) built of ≈øtone aboue a mans hight. And finally An. 1505. all Chanteries Colledges & ho≈øpitals were giueÃÑ to the K. And yet not
content withall the≈øe Church goods,VVhat mi≈øcheef one point of Prote≈øancie brought to England. which were ine≈øtimable, within two years after, to wit An. 1540. impo≈øed a great tax vpon both Clergy & Layty as neuer was heard of before in England, as yow may read in Stow & other. And withall coined ba≈øe mony in great aboundance which was after called downe to halfe valowe,Prote≈øtancie at fir≈øt entrance vndid English men, ≈øoules bodies goods, hou≈øes, Churches monuments. Thus yow may ≈øee how Prote≈øtancie or rather one pointe therof, to wit, The deniall of the Popes ≈øupremacie altered this K. from a liberall and clement Prince, to a mo≈øt cruel & couetous maÃÑ, & how it entred into our CouÃÑtry, not only with the lo≈ø≈øe of our Contrymens ≈øoules, but al≈øo of their goods and liues, & made ≈øuch hauock of meÃÑ & weemeÃÑ, of churches, hou≈øes, ancient Monuments, ≈øtately buildings as if ≈øome fury had come out of Hel, or ≈øomme mortall enemy had gon roging vp & down our Contry.Prote≈øtaÃÑts vvish of Geneua and Beza. And the DaÃÑgerous Po≈øitioner l. 1. c. vlt. ≈øaith he thincketh the Scottish Mini≈øters wrought more mi≈øcheefe in that Country in 30. years thaÃÑ the P. of Rome had done before, in 500.

3.Mi≈øerable ≈øucce≈ø≈øe after Prote≈øancie. Finally the ≈øucces which this King reaped by his alteration was mo≈øt mi≈øerable. For wheras before he was loued of Engli≈øh-men at home, and feared of ≈øtrangers abroad, after this change made, he was ≈øecure of neither. For fir≈øt Lincoln≈øhyre men ro≈øe again≈øt him to the number of 20. thou≈øand,Commotions. & ≈øtreight after York≈øhier men to the nuÃÑber of 40. thou≈øand. The meanes by which it was ≈øet vp was nether miracle nor extordinarie vertue of the fir≈øt preachers of it or their publick confuting by di≈øputation their aduer≈øaries as Catholick religion was ≈øet vp by S. Au≈øtin,Frocurers laie men. but meerely the will of the Protector in King Edwards time, and of the Qeeene in her time, and the terror of lawes. Edwards time, who ≈øtuck not to tell euen in that time to M. Catholick faith, and profe≈ø≈øed that he did not for hope of life, but for con≈øcience, and acknowledged the euils then hapned to England to haue comen by the new religion By this iudg of the re≈øt and now let vs return to Luther.

div.head: CHAP. VII. That Luther was ignorant or meanly learned,
div.p: 1 Luthers yong years.1. THat Luther was but meanly learned wheÃÑ he fir≈øt begaÃÑ Prote≈øtaÃÑti≈øme I wil proue many waies. Fir≈øt by his yong years for he was but 34. years ould when he began this new doctrine. At what yeares men haue rather the ground of learning,2 Studied in no famous vniuers. 2. Fourthly I proue Luthers ignorance by his doctrine. For as Feild lib. 4 of the

To fight again≈øt the Turk is to repugne again≈øt God Soules in purgatory do ≈øin without intermi≈øsioÃÑ, & diuers others which Fox is faine to file with his expo≈øitioÃÑ, D. 4. La≈øtly,Luthers confe≈øsioÃÑ of his ingnorance. Sleidan Engl. lib. 16. fol. 232. vvhen Luth began fir≈øt-to preach again≈øt pardon he knevv not vvhat that matter ment as him ≈ø ‚Ä¢ lf confe≈ø≈øeth. And in Fox pag. 1173. he confe≈ø≈øeth that he is not certaine, what is done with a ≈øoul which departing without actuall ≈øin yet hath the originall roate of ≈øin, nor whither Fear in a man dying with imperfect charitie let his entrance into heauen or no. And was this the man that controlled all the Fathers? that condemned al Antiquitie of ignoraÃÑce and blindnes? that contemned al the Canoni≈øts & ≈øchole diuines? was this the God (as ≈øome call him) of diuins? was this the conductor of I≈ørael? was this the man that was giuen by God to lighten the vvorld? Mini≈øters. what may we think of others who ≈øucceded him? Some of our Mini≈øters (≈øaith Collins in his ≈øermoÃÑ at Pauls Cro≈ø≈øe 1607.) are enemies to learning. The Declaration of di≈øciplin printed at Geneua an. 1580. ≈øaith p. 148. That now in ≈øteed
of labor idlenes is comen into the vniuer≈øities, contention, neglect and almo≈øt contempt of all religion with di≈ø≈øolute licence and libertie, wherby they giue them ≈øelues to all riot and wantones. div.head: CHAP. VIII. That Luther was a naughtie and vicious man.Three kinds of proof of Luthers vice
div.p:
1. MY proofes of Luthers vicious and naughtie life I will reduce to three
heads. The fir≈øt ≈øhalbe touching his owne deeds. The ≈øecond touching his doctrine. And the third touching the effects of bothe. As for his life it ≈øeemeth that for a while after he entred into S. Au≈øtins order he did ≈øeriou≈øly giue him ≈øelf to pietie and deuotion. For that he writeth of him ≈øelf while he was a Frier 1. Galat. fol. 37 I endeuored my ≈øelf to keep the Popes laws as much as was po≈øsible for me to doe, Luthers pietie for the time of his Cath. religion. punishing my poore bodie with fa≈øting, watching, praying and other exerci≈øes. I honored the Pope of mere con≈øcience & vnfainedly and what≈øoeuer I did, I did it of a ≈øingle hart of good zeall and for the glorie of God. And fol. 38. I keept cha≈øtity pouerty and obedience, I was free from the cares of this pre≈øent life, I was onely giuen to fa≈øting, vvatching, praying. Thus Luther for a time, and happie had he bene if he had ≈øo continewed. But as he entred into religion vpon fear becau≈øe he with whome he walked in the feilds was there ≈ølaine with a thunderbolt. So fear being an il keeper of continuance, he afterward fell from this zeall of his owne good & Gods glorie, and in ≈øteed therof fo≈øtered (as him ≈øelf writeth fol. 38.) cit. coÃÑtinuall mi≈øtru≈øt doubtfulnes and hatred & bla≈øphemie again≈øt God. Luther confe≈ø≈øeth that he hated God And praefat. 1. operum tom. 1. I felt my ≈øelf (≈øaith he) to be before God of a mo≈øt trobled con≈øcience, I loued not yea I hated (√¥ horor to hear) God iu≈øt and punishing ≈øinnes, and vvith ≈øecret if not bla≈øphemie
yet vvith great murmuring I repined at him. Luthers fit di≈øpo≈øition to become an Archeretik. I raged ≈øo vvith a feare and perturbed con≈øcience. Thus Luther of him ≈øelf before he began Prote≈øtanti≈øme. And I pray the Chri≈øtian Reader was this change in Luther from zeall of Gods glorie to hatred of God, from God or from the diuel? was a man in this ca≈øe likelie to haue particuler light from God touching his truth rather than anie in the world be≈øides? Or rather hauing (as him ≈øelf confe≈ø≈øeth) lo≈øt a good con≈øcience, was he not like (as S.
